[24:62] Now Isaac had come from Beer-lahai-roi, and was settled in the Negeb.[24:63] In the evening, when Isaac had gone out for a walk in the field, he looked up and saw camels coming.[24:64] Rebekah too looked up, and when she saw Isaac, she quickly alighted from the camel[24:65] and said to the servant, “Who is this man walking in the field to meet us?” When the servant said, “It is my master,” she took her veil and covered her face.[24:66] Then the servant told Isaac all that he had done.[24:67] Isaac brought Rebekah to the tent of Sarah his mother, and she became his wife; and he loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.

 [Genesis 25] 

##### Geneaology, Abraham’s death #####

[25:1] Abraham had taken another wife, whose name was Keturah.[25:2] She gave him sons: Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.[25:3] Jokshan fathered Sheba, and Dedan. T he sons of Dedan were Asshurim, Letushim, and Leummim;[25:4] and the sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.

[25:5] Abraham had left all that he had to Isaac.[25:6] But to the sons of his concubines, Abraham had given gifts while he was still alive, and had sent them away from Isaac his son, eastward, to the east country.

[25:7] Abraham had lived for one hundred and seventy-five years,[25:8] when he breathed his last, dying in a good old age, old and satisfied with living, and was gathered to his forefathers.

[25:9] Then Isaac and Ishmael his sons buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron the son of Zohar the Hittite, which is east of Mamre,[25:10] the field which Abraham purchased from the Hittites. There Abraham was buried with Sarah his wife.

[25:11] After the death of Abraham, God blessed Isaac his son, who settled at Beer-lahai-roi.

[25:12] This is a list of descedents of Ishmael, Abraham’s son whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s maid-servant gave to Abraham.[25:13] These then are the names of the sons of Ishmael, named according to their order of birth: the first-born of Ishmael, Nebaioth; then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,[25:14] Mishma, Dumah, Massa,[25:15] Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.[25:16] These are the sons of Ishmael, and these are their names, by their villages, and by their encampments, twelve princes according to their peoples.

[25:17] Ishmael lived for one hundred and thirty-seven years; and he breathed his last, and was gathered to his people.[25:18] They settled from Havilah to Shur that iseast of Egypt, as far as Assyria; he settled down alongside all his people.

[25:19] These are the descendants of Isaac, Abraham’s son. Abraham fathered Isaac.[25:20] Isaac was forty years old, when he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramean of Paddan-aram, the sister of Laban the Aramean.

##### Esau and Jacob #####

[25:21] Isaac prayed to the LORD  for his wife, because she had no children; and the LORD  heard his prayer, and Rebekah became pregnant with twins.[25:22] The children struggled against each other in her womb, and she said, “Why is this happening to me? What does it mean?” She went to ask the LORD,[25:23] who said to her,

|  “Two nations are in your womb,
|    two peoples divided from birth,
|  One will be stronger than the other,
|    the elder will serve the younger.”

[25:24] When the time came for her to give birth, she became the mother of twin boys.[25:25] The first was from birth red, all over like a hairy mantle; so they named him Esau^[ Hairy].[25:26] Afterwards his brother came holding Esau’s heel with his hand; so he was named Jacob^[ Supplanter]. Isaac was sixty years old when they were born.

[25:27] As they grew up, Esau became a skilful hunter, a man who lived out in the fields; but Jacob was a quiet man who stayed about the tents.[25:28] Isaac loved Esau, for he had a taste for venison; but Rebekah loved Jacob.

[25:29] Once when Jacob was preparing a stew, Esau came in from the fields, and he was very hungry;[25:30] so he said to Jacob, “Let me swallow some of that red stew, for I am very hungry.” (This is why he was called Edom.)[25:31] But Jacob said, “Sell me first of all your right as the eldest.”[25:32] Esau replied, “See, I am nearly dead now! So of what use is this birthright to me?”[25:33] Jacob said, “First solemnly promise to give it to me.” So Esau solemnly promised and sold his birthright to Jacob.[25:34] Then Jacob gave Esau bread and stewed lentils, and when he had finished eating and drinking, he got up and went away. In this way Esau gave away his birthright.

 [Genesis 26] 

##### Famine again #####

[26:1] Now when a famine came in the land, (not the first famine that was in the days of Abraham), Isaac went to Abimelech king of the Philistines at Gerar.

[26:2] The LORD  appeared to him and said, “Go not down into Egypt; settle in the land of which I will tell you,[26:3] stay in this land, and I will be with you and will bless you; for to you, and to your descendants, I will give all these lands, and will establish the oath which I swore to Abraham your father:[26:4] I will make your descendants as many as the stars of heaven, and give to your descendants all these lands; and all the nations of the earth will invoke for themselves a blessing like that of your descendants,[26:5] because Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my charge, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws.”[26:6] So Isaac settled in Gerar.

[26:7] The men of the place asked him about his wife; and he said, “She is my sister”; for he was afraid to say “my wife”; lest the men of the place kill him for Rebekah; because she was beautiful to look at.[26:8] But after he had been there a long time, Abimelech king of the Philistines looked out of the window, and saw Isaac just as he was caressing Rebekah his wife.

[26:9] Then Abimelech called to Isaac, and said, “Surely she is your wife; why did you say ‘She is my sister?’” Isaac answered him, “I said it, so that I might not die because of her.”[26:10] Abimelech said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the people might have lain with your wife and so you would have brought guilt upon us.”[26:11] Abimelech warned all the people, saying, “The person who touches this man or his wife will be put to death.”

[26:12] Then Isaac sowed in that land, and reaped in the same year an increase of a hundredfold, for the LORD  blessed him.[26:13] The man became rich, and grew richer and richer until he became very wealthy; for he had many flocks, and many herds, and a great household; so that the Philistines envied him.

[26:14] Now all the wells which Isaac’s father’s servants had dug in the days of Abraham his father, the Philistines had stopped, and filled with earth.[26:15] But Isaac dug again the wells of water, which they had dug in the days of Abraham his father — for the Philistines had stopped them after the death of Abraham and he gave them the same names as his father had given them.

[26:16] Abimelech said to Isaac, “Go from us; for you are much mightier than we are.”[26:17] So Isaac departed, and encamped in the valley of Gerar, and settled there.[26:18] Isaac reopened the wells which had been dug in the days of his father Abraham and stopped by the Philistines after his death. He called them by the names his father had given them.[26:19] When Isaac’s slaves dug in the valley, they found there a well of spring water.[26:20] The herdsmen of Gerar quarreled with Isaac’s herdsmen, saying, “The water is ours.” So he called the name of the well Esek^[ Contention], because they contended with him.[26:21] And when they dug another well, they quarreled over that also. So he called the name of it Sitnah^[ Enmity].[26:22] He moved on from these and dug another well; and over that one there was no dispute. So he called it Rehoboth^[ Room], and said, “For now the LORD  has made room for us and we shall be fruitful in the land.”

[26:23] Isaac went up from there to Beer-sheba.[26:24] The LORD  appeared to him the same night and said, “I am the God of Abraham your father, do not be afraid, because I am with you, and will bless you and make your descendants numerous for the sake of my servant Abraham.”[26:25] Isaac built an altar there, and called upon the name of the LORD, and pitched his tent there. There also Isaac’s slaves dug a well.

[26:26] Then Abimelech came to him from Gerar with Ahuzzath his friend, and Phicol the captain of his army.[26:27] Isaac said to them, “Why have you come to me, since you hated me and have driven me away from you?”[26:28] They said, “We saw plainly that the LORD  was with you, so we said, ‘Let there now be a sworn treaty between us — let us make a solemn agreement with you —[26:29] so that you will do us no harm, as we have not touched you, and as we have done to you nothing but good, and have sent you away in peace.’ You are now blessed of the LORD .”[26:30] And he made them a feast and they ate and drank.[26:31] Then in the morning they arose early and took oaths with each other; and Isaac sent them away, and they departed from him in peace.[26:32] That same day, Isaac’s slaves came and told him about a well which they had dug, and said to him, “We have found water.”[26:33] He called it Shebna^[ Oath], therefore the name of the city is Beer-sheba to this day.

##### Esau and Jacob #####

[26:34] When Esau was forty years old he married Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite,[26:35] and they were a source of grief to Isaac and to Rebekah.

 [Genesis 27] 

[27:1] When Isaac was so old and so nearly blind that he could not see, he called Esau his oldest son and said to him, “My son.” Esau answered, “Here I am.”[27:2] Isaac said, “See, I am old and do not know how soon I may die.[27:3] T ake your quiver and your bow and go out into the fields and hunt venison for me[27:4] and prepare for me savory food, such as I love, and bring it to me that I may eat and that I may bless you before I die.”

[27:5] Rebekah was listening when Isaac spoke to his son Esau. So when Esau went into the fields to hunt venison,[27:6] Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “I just now heard your father say to your brother Esau,[27:7] ‘Bring me venison and prepare for me savory food that I may eat it and bless you before I die.’[27:8] Now, my son, do as I tell you:[27:9] Go to the flock and bring me from there two good young goats, and I will make of them savory food for your father, such as he loves.[27:10] Then take it to him, so that he may eat, so that he may bless you before he dies.”[27:11] But Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, “You know that my brother Esau is a hairy man, while I am smooth.[27:12] Perhaps my father will touch me; then I will appear to him to be a deceiver, and I will bring blame upon me and not a blessing.”[27:13] But his mother said to him, “Let the curse be on me, my son; only obey me and go, bring the goats to me.”[27:14] So he went and brought them to his mother, and his mother made savory food such as his father loved.

[27:15] Rebekah also took the fine clothes of her older son Esau, which she had with her in the tent, and put them on her younger son Jacob.[27:16] Then she put the skins of the goats upon his hands and upon the smooth part of his neck,[27:17] and she placed the savory food and the bread which she had prepared in his hand,[27:18] and he went to his father and said, “My father.” Isaac answered, “Here I am; who are you, my son?”[27:19] Jacob said, “I am Esau your oldest son. I have done as you commanded me. Sit up and eat some of my venison, so that you may bless me.”[27:20] Isaac said to his son, “How very quickly you have found it, my son.” He answered, “Yes, because the LORD  your God gave me success.”

[27:21] Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come here, my son, that I may touch you to find out whether you are really my son Esau or not.”[27:22] So Jacob went near to Isaac his father, and he felt him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.[27:23-24] Are you really my son Esau?” Jacob answered, “I am.” Isaac did not recognize him, for his hands were hairy like his brother Esau’s. So he blessed him.[27:25] Then Isaac said, “Bring the food to me, that I may eat some of my son’s venison and bless you.” So he brought it to him, and he ate. Jacob also brought him wine, and he drank.

[27:26] Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come near now and kiss me, my son.”[27:27] As he came near and kissed him, he smelled the smell of his garment, and blessed him:

|  See, the smell of my son
|    is as that of fields blessed by the LORD .
|  [27:28] May God give you dew from heaven,
|    a share in the earth’s fertile places,
|    and plenty of corn and wine.
|  [27:29] May peoples be subject to you,
|    and nations bow down to you.
|  Be master over your brothers.
|    Let your mother’s sons bow down before you,
|  Cursed be all who curse you.
|    and blessed be all who bless you.

[27:30] As soon as Isaac had given Jacob his blessing, and Jacob was about to leave his father, Esau his brother came in from his hunting.[27:31] He also had made savory food and was bringing it to his father. So he said to him, “Father, rise and eat of your son’s venison, that you may bless me.”[27:32] But Isaac his father said to him, “Who are you?” He answered, “I am your son, your oldest, Esau.”[27:33] Then Isaac trembled and said, “Who then is he that has hunted venison and brought it to me, so that I ate plentifully before you came, and blessed him? His blessing cannot be undone!”

[27:34] When Esau heard the words of his father, he uttered a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Father, bless me also!”

[27:35] But Isaac said, “Your brother came with deceit and has taken away your blessing.”[27:36] Esau said, “He was correctly named Jacob^[ means Supplanter]. He has supplanted me these two times: he took my birthright, and now he has taken my blessing!” Then he said, “Have you kept a blessing for me?”[27:37] Isaac answered Esau, “I have made him your master and I have given to him all his relatives as slaves and grain and wine as his food. What then can I do for you, my son?”[27:38] Esau said to his father, “Is that the only blessing you have, my father? Father, bless me too!” and Esau began to weep aloud.[27:39] Then Isaac his father answered him:

|  “You shall live far from earth’s fertile places,
|    and away from the dew of heaven.
|  [27:40] By your sword you will live,
|    and your brother you will serve.
|  But whenever you will break loose,
|    you will break off his yoke from your neck.”

[27:41] Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing that his father had given him. Esau said to himself, “My father will soon die; then I will kill Jacob, my brother.”

[27:42] When the words of her older son Esau were told to Rebekah, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, “Your brother, Esau, is going to kill you.[27:43] Now, my son, listen to me: run away to my brother Laban at Haran[27:44] and stay with him for a time until your brother is no longer angry[27:45] — until he is no longer angry and he forgets what you have done to him. Then I will send and bring you back. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”

##### Wives for Jacob and Esau #####

[27:46] Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am disgusted with life because of the Hittite women; if Jacob marries a Hittite woman, such as these, the women of the land, I might as well die.”

 [Genesis 28] 

[28:1] Then Isaac called Jacob, and blessed him, and instructed him, “You must not marry any of the daughters of Canaan.[28:2] Arise, go to Paddan-aram, to the house of Bethuel your mother’s father; and marry one of the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.[28:3] May God Almighty bless you, and make you fruitful and numerous, so that you may become a great people,[28:4] and may he give the blessing of Abraham to you and to your descendants with you so that you may inherit the land you have settled in, which God gave to Abraham.”

[28:5] So Isaac sent away Jacob, and he went to Paddan-aram to Laban, the son of Bethuel the Aramean, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob and Esau’s mother.[28:6] Now when Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and send him away to Paddan-aram, to find a wife there, and that, as he blessed him, he instructed him: “You must not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan”,[28:7] and that Jacob had obeyed his father and mother, and had gone to Paddan-aram,[28:8] and when Esau also saw that the daughters of Canaan did not please Isaac his father,[28:9] then Esau went to Ishmael, and in addition to the wives that he had, married Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, the sister of Nebaioth.

##### Jacob and the ladder #####

[28:10] Then Jacob set out from Beersheba and went toward Haran.[28:11] When he arrived at a certain holy place, he passed the night there, because the sun had set. He took one of the stones from its place and put it under his head and lay down to sleep.[28:12] Then he dreamed and saw a ladder set up on the earth, and its top reached to heaven; and the messengers of God were going up and down on it.

[28:13] The LORD  also stood beside him and said, “I am the LORD, God of Abraham and God of Isaac. The land on which you lie I will give to you and to your children.[28:14] Your descendants will be as countless as the dust of the earth and you will spread abroad to the west, and to the east, and to the north, and to the south, and all the families of the earth will wish for a blessing like yours and that of your descendants.[28:15] See, I am with you, and will keep you wherever you go and will bring you again to this land; for I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”

[28:16] When Jacob awoke from his sleep, he said, “Surely the LORD  is in this place, and I did not know it.”[28:17] And he was filled with awe and said, “This place is the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven.”

[28:18] So Jacob rose early in the morning and took the stone that he had put under his head and set it up as a pillar and poured oil upon the top of it.[28:19] He named that place Bethel^[ which means House of God]. (The earlier name of the town was Luz.)[28:20] Jacob also made this promise, “If God will be with me and protect me on this journey which I am making and give me bread to eat and clothing to put on,[28:21] and if I return safe and sound to my father’s house, then the LORD  shall be my God,[28:22] and this stone which I have set up as a pillar will be a house of God. And of all that you give me I will surely give a tenth to you.”

 [Genesis 29] 

##### Leah and Rachel #####

[29:1] Jacob continued on his journey and arrived at the land of the people of the East.[29:2] He looked and saw a well in the field, and there were three flocks of sheep lying down by it; for from that well they watered the flocks; but there was a large stone over the well.[29:3] When all the flocks were gathered there, the shepherds used to roll away the stone and water the sheep and then put the stone back in its place over the well.

[29:4] Jacob said to the men, “My friends, from where do you come?” They said, “We are from Haran.”[29:5] Then he said to them, “Do you know Laban the son of Nahor?” They said, “We know him.”[29:6] He said to them, “Is all well with him?” They said, “All is well; indeed, this is Rachel his daughter coming with the sheep.”[29:7] H e said, “See, the sun is still high! It is not time for the cattle to be gathered together. Water the sheep and feed them.”[29:8] But they said, “We cannot until all the flocks are gathered together, and they roll away the stone from the well; then we will water the sheep.”

[29:9] While he was still speaking with them, Rachel came with her father’s sheep; for she was a shepherdess.[29:10] When Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of Laban, his mother’s brother, and Laban’s sheep, he went up and rolled the stone from the well and watered the flock of Laban his mother’s brother.[29:11] Then Jacob kissed Rachel and wept aloud.[29:12] When Jacob told Rachel that he was a relative of her father and that he was Rebekah’s son, she ran and told her father.

[29:13] As soon as Laban heard about Jacob, his sister’s son, he ran to meet him, put his arms around him, kissed him many times, and brought him to his home. When Jacob told Laban all that had happened,[29:14] Laban said to him, “Surely you are my bone and my flesh.” So he remained with him a whole month.

[29:15] Then Laban said to Jacob, “Should you serve me for nothing simply because you are related to me? Tell me what shall be your wages?”[29:16] Now Laban had two daughters: the name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.[29:17] Leah’s eyes were dull, but Rachel was beautiful.[29:18] Jacob loved Rachel, and so he said, “I will serve you seven years for Rachel your younger daughter.”[29:19] Laban said, “It is better for me to give her to you than to give her to any other man. Stay with me.”[29:20] So Jacob served seven years for Rachel, and they seemed to him but a few days, because he loved her so.

[29:21] Then Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife, for my time is up, and let me marry her.”[29:22] So Laban gathered all the men of the place and made a feast.[29:23] In the evening he took Leah his daughter and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob received her as his wife.[29:24] At the same time Laban gave his slave-girl Zilpah to his daughter Leah.

[29:25] When in the morning Jacob found it was Leah, he said to Laban, “What is this you have done to me? Did I not serve you for Rachel? Why then have you deceived me?”[29:26] Laban said, “It is not the custom among us to give the younger in marriage before the older.[29:27] Remain with this one during the marriage week, then we will give you the other also for the service which you will give me during seven more years.”[29:28] Jacob did so: he remained with Leah during the marriage week. Then Laban gave him Rachel his daughter to be his wife,[29:29] and his slave-girl Bilhah to serve Rachel.[29:30] Jacob slept with Rachel as well, and loved Rachel more than Leah. So he had to serve Laban seven years more.

[29:31] When the LORD  saw that Leah was spurned, he gave her the gift of motherhood; Rachel, however, was barren.[29:32] So Leah gave birth to a son whom she named Reuben^[ Behold a son]; for she said, “The LORD  has seen my affliction; now my husband will love me.”[29:33] She gave birth to another son; and said, “Because the LORD  has heard that I am spurned, he has given me this one also”; and she called his name Simeon^[ Hearing].[29:34] She gave birth to another son and said, “Now this time my husband will become attached to me because I have borne him three sons”; therefore his name was called Levi^[ Attached].[29:35] She gave birth to another son and said, “This time I will praise the LORD ”; therefore she called his name Judah^[ Praise] then she stopped having children.

 [Genesis 30] 

[30:1] When Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no children, she was jealous of her sister and said to Jacob, “Give me children or else I will die.”[30:2] But Jacob’s anger was aroused against Rachel, and he said, “Am I in God’s place? Who has withheld offspring from you?”[30:3] She said, “Here is my slave-girl Bilhah, go to her, so that she may bear sons who can be laid on my knees and I also may obtain children though her.”[30:4] So she gave him Bilhah her slave-girl for a wife, and Jacob slept with her.[30:5] When Bilhah conceived and bore Jacob a son,[30:6] Rachel said, “God has judged me and has also heard my voice and has given me a son.” So she called his name Dan^[ He judged].

[30:7] Bilhah, Rachel’s slave-girl conceived again, and bore Jacob a second son.[30:8] Rachel said, “With superhuman wrestlings have I wrestled with my sister, and have prevailed”; so she called his name Naphtali^[ Obtained by wrestling].

[30:9] When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took Zilpah her slave-girl, and gave her to Jacob as a wife.[30:10] Zilpah, Leah’s slave-girl bore Jacob a son.[30:11] Leah said, “Fortunate!” and she called his name Gad.[30:12] Zilpah bore Jacob a second son,[30:13] and Leah said, “Happy am I! Now women will call me happy”, and she called his name Asher.

[30:14] One time, during the wheat harvest, Reuben went and found mandrakes in the field and brought them to his mother Leah. Rachel asked Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”[30:15] But Leah said to her, “Is it a small matter that you have taken away my husband, that you would also take away my son’s mandrakes?” Rachel said, “In exchange for your son’s mandrakes, Jacob can sleep with you tonight.”[30:16] So when Jacob came from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him, and said, “You sleep with me tonight, for I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.” So he slept with her that night.

[30:17] God heard Leah’s prayer, and she conceived and bore Jacob a fifth son.[30:18] Leah said, “God has given me my reward, because I gave my slave-girl to my husband”; so she called his name Issachar^[ There is a hire].[30:19] Leah conceived again, and bore a sixth son to Jacob.[30:20] She said, “God has endowed me with a good dowry; now my husband will honor me, because I have borne him six sons”; and she called him Zebulun^[ Dwelling].[30:21] And afterwards she had a daughter and named her Dinah.

[30:22] Then God remembered Rachel and heard her prayer and gave her a child.[30:23] She conceived and gave birth to a son and said, “God has taken away my disgrace.”[30:24] She called his name Joseph^[ He will add], saying, “the LORD  will add to me another son.”

[30:25] When Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me away, so that I may go to my own place, and to my country.[30:26] Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served you, so that I may go; for you know the service which I have rendered you.”[30:27] But Laban said to him, “If now I have found favor in your eyes — I have divined that the LORD  has blessed me for your sake.[30:28] State exactly to me your wages and I will pay them.”

[30:29] Jacob answered him, “You know how I have served you and what your cattle have become under my care;[30:30] for it was little which you had before I came, but now it has greatly increased, since the LORD  has blessed you wherever I went. But now, when am I to provide for my own house as well?”[30:31] Laban said, “What should I give you?”

Jacob said, “You do not need to give me anything. If you will do this thing for me, I will again feed your flock; I will again keep it.[30:32] If I can go through all your flock today, and remove from it every black one among the lambs and the spotted and speckled among the goats; these will be my wages.[30:33] So my honesty will testify for me later, when you come to inspect my wages: every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats and black among the lambs has been stolen by me.”[30:34] Laban said, “Good, let it be as you say.”[30:35] But he removed that day the he-goats that were striped and spotted, and all the she-goats that were striped and spotted, every one that had white on it, and all the black ones among the lambs, and gave them into the hands of his sons.[30:36] Then he put the distance of a three days’ journey between himself and Jacob; and Jacob fed the rest of Laban’s flocks.

[30:37] Jacob, however, took fresh rods of white poplar, and of the almond and of the plane tree, and peeled white streaks in them, exposing the white which was in the rods.[30:38] He set the rods which he had peeled before the flocks in the watering-troughs where the flocks came to drink (and they conceived when they came to drink)[30:39] so that the flocks conceived before the rods. Therefore the flocks brought forth striped, speckled and spotted offspring.[30:40] Jacob separated the lambs, and he set the faces of the flocks toward the striped and the black animals in the flock of Laban and he put his own droves apart and did not put them near Laban’s flock.

[30:41] Whenever the stronger animals of the flock conceived, Jacob laid the rods in the troughs before the eyes of the flock, so that they might conceive among the rods.[30:42] But when the animals were weak, he did not put them in.In this way the weaker became Laban’s, and the stronger Jacobs’s.

[30:43] So the man increased in wealth exceedingly, and had large flocks, and male and female slaves, and camels and donkeys.

 [Genesis 31] 

[31:1] Now Jacob heard Laban’s sons say, “Jacob has taken all that was our father’s, and from that which was our father’s he has acquired all these riches.”[31:2] Now Jacob observed that Laban was not so favorably inclined to him as formerly.[31:3] The LORD  said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your ancestors, and to your relatives, and I will be with you.”[31:4] Then Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah to come to the field where his flocks were,[31:5] and said to them, “I see that your father is not so favorably inclined toward me as formerly; but the God of my father has been with me.[31:6] You know that I have served your father with all my strength.[31:7] Your father, however, has deceived me and changed my wages ten times; but God has not allowed him to do me harm.[31:8] If your father said, ‘The speckled will be your wages,’ then all the flock bore speckled offspring, but if he said: ‘The striped will be your wages,’ then all the flock have striped offspring.[31:9] God has taken away the possessions of your father and given them to me.[31:10] At the time when the flock breed, I looked up, and saw in a dream, that the he-goats which were mating were striped, speckled, and piebald.[31:11] The messenger of God said to me in a dream, ‘Jacob!’ and I said, ‘Here I am.’[31:12] And he said, ‘Look! All the he-goats which are mating are striped, speckled, and piebald: for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.[31:13] I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar of stone, where you made a vow to me. Now arise, leave this land, and return to the land where you were born.’”

[31:14] Then Rachel and Leah answered him, “There is no longer any inheritance for us in our father’s house.[31:15] Are we not considered as foreigners by him? For he has sold us and goes on to consume the money paid for us.[31:16] Since all the riches which God has taken away from our father is ours and our children’s, do whatever God has told you to do.”

[31:17] Then Jacob rose up and put his sons and his wives on camels,[31:18] and drove away all his cattle and all the cattle which he had acquired in Paddan-aram, in order to go to Isaac his father, to the land of Canaan.[31:19] And while Laban was gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole the household gods that were her father’s.[31:20] So Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean — he did not tell him that he was going to flee.[31:21] So he fled with all he had; crossing the river Euphrates heading towards the hill-country of Gilead.

[31:22] When it was reported to Laban on the third day that Jacob had fled,[31:23] he took his tribesmen with him, and pursued him for seven days, and overtook him in the hill country of Gilead.[31:24] But God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night, and said to him, “Take care that you do not speak to Jacob either good or bad.”[31:25] When Laban caught up with Jacob, Jacob had pitched his tent in the hill country; and Laban with his relatives encamped in same hill country of Gilead.

[31:26] Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done? You have deceived me and carried away my daughters like captives of war![31:27] Why did you flee secretly, stealing away from me without telling me? I would have sent you away with mirth and with songs, with tambourine and with harp —[31:28] but you did not allow me to kiss my sons and daughters. You have acted foolishly.[31:29] It was in my power to do you harm, but the God of your father spoke to me last night saying, ‘Take care that you do not speak to Jacob, neither good nor bad.’[31:30] But now, since you are surely going because you long so earnestly for your father’s house, why have you stolen my gods?”

[31:31] Jacob answered Laban, “I was afraid, because I thought you would take your daughters from me by force.[31:32] The one with whom you find your gods will be put to death; in the presence of our kinsmen investigate for yourself what is with me and take it.” Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen Laban’s gods.[31:33] So Laban went into Jacob’s tent and into Leah’s, and into the tent of the two slave-girls, but he did not find his gods. Then he went out of Leah’s tent, and entered Rachel’s.[31:34] Now Rachel had taken the household gods and put them in the camel’s saddle and was sitting on them, so that when Laban had searched all about the tent, he did not find them.[31:35] She said to her father, “Do not be angry that I cannot rise before you, my lord, for it is that time of the month that women have.” And though he searched thoroughly, he did not find the household gods.

[31:36] Then Jacob became angry and challenged Laban. “What is my crime?” he said, “What is my offense, that you have pursued hotly after me?[31:37] Alhough you have gone through all through my things, what have you found of all your household possessions? Declare it here before my kinsmen and yours, so that they may decide which of us two is in the right.[31:38] In all these twenty years that have I been with you, your ewes and she-goats have not miscarried their young, neither did I eat the rams of your flocks.[31:39] I did not bring to you the animals which were killed by wild beasts; I bore the loss of it myself; from my hand you required compensation, whether stolen by day or stolen by night.[31:40] This was how I was: in the day the heat consumed me, and by night the frost, and sleep deserted me.[31:41] These twenty years I have been in your house; I served you fourteen years for your two daughters, and six years for your flock, and you have changed my wages ten times.[31:42] Unless the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had been with me, surely by now you would have sent me away empty. But God has seen my affliction and the labor of my hands, and he rebuked you last night.”

[31:43] Then Laban answered Jacob, “The daughters are my daughters, and the children are my grandchildren, and the flocks are my flocks, and all that you see is mine, but what can I do today for these my daughters, or for their children whom they have borne?[31:44] Come, let us make a solemn agreement, I and you, and let there be a witness between me and you.”

[31:45] So Jacob took a stone, and set it up as a pillar,[31:46] and said to the members of his family, “Gather stones.” When they had taken stones and made a heap, they ate there by the heap.[31:47] Laban called it Jegar-sahaduthap^[ Heap of witness]; but Jacob called it Galeed^[ Heap of witness].[31:48] “This heap”, Laban said, “is witness between me and you today.” This is why it was called Galeed,[31:49] and Mizpah^[ Place of watching], for Laban said, “May the LORD  watch between me and you when we are absent one from another,[31:50] so that you may not maltreat my daughters nor take other wives besides my daughters. No one is with us; but beware: God is witness between me and you.”

[31:51] Moreover, Laban said to Jacob, “See this heap, and the pillar which I have set up between me and you.[31:52] This heap is a witness and the pillar is a witness that I should not pass beyond this heap to you and that you must not pass beyond this heap and this pillar to me, with hostile intent.[31:53] The God of Abraham and the God of Nahor” (the God of their ancestors) “judge between us.” And Jacob swore by the Fear of his father Isaac.

[31:54] Then Jacob offered a sacrifice there on the mountain and called his kinsmen to eat bread, and they ate bread and spent the night on the mountain.

[31:55] Then early in the morning Laban arose, and, when he had kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them, he departed and returned to his home.

 [Genesis 32] 

[32:1] Jacob went on his way and the messengers of God met him.[32:2] When he saw them, Jacob said, “This is God’s camp;” so he named the place “Mahanaim^[ Company].”

##### Jacob prepares to meet Esau #####

[32:3] Jacob sent messengers before him to his brother Esau, to the land of Seir, which is the territory of the Edomites.[32:4] He gave them this command, “Say to my lord Esau: ‘Your servant Jacob declares, I have lived with Laban and have stayed until now.[32:5] I have oxen and donkeys, flocks and male and female slaves, and I have sent to tell my lord, in order that I may win your favor.’”[32:6] The messengers returned to Jacob with the report, “We came to your brother Esau, even as he was coming to meet you with four hundred men.”

[32:7] Then Jacob was greatly alarmed and worried. So he divided the people that were with him and the flocks and the herds and the camels into two parts[32:8] and said, “If Esau comes to the one and attacks and destroys it, then the other which is left can escape.”

[32:9] Jacob also prayed, “God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, LORD  who said to me, ‘Return to your country, and to your relatives, and I will do well by you,’[32:10] I am not worthy of the least of all the mercies and all the faithfulness which you have shown to me, your servant. I passed over the Jordan river with only my staff, and now I have these two groups,[32:11] deliver me, I pray, from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I fear that he will come and attack me and kill the mothers and the children.[32:12] Remember your promise to make me prosper and my descendants as many as the sand of the seashore, uncountable.”

[32:13] After spending the night there, Jacob took from his livestock as a present for his brother Esau,[32:14] two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,[32:15] thirty milch camels and their young, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten young donkeys.[32:16] These he put, each drove by itself, in the care of his servants and said to them, “Go on before me and leave a space between the droves.”

[32:17] He gave those in front this command: “When my brother Esau meets you and asks you, ‘To whom do you belong? And where are you going? And whose are these before you?’[32:18] then you shall say, ‘To your servant Jacob; it is a present sent by him to my lord Esau; and Jacob himself is just behind us.’”[32:19] Jacob also commanded the second, and the third, and all that followed the droves, to make the same answer,[32:20] and to say, “Jacob himself is just behind us.” For he said to himself, “I will please him with the present that goes before me, and then, when I meet him, perhaps he will welcome me.”[32:21] So he sent the present over before him; but he himself spent that night in the camp.

[32:22] Later that night he rose up and took his two wives, his two slave-girls, and his eleven children, and sent them over the river Jabbok.

##### Jacob wrestles #####

[32:23] After he had sent them accross with all his belongings,[32:24] Jacob was left alone, and someone wrestled with him until daybreak.[32:25] When he saw that he did not win against Jacob, he struck the socket of his hip, and the socket of Jacob’s hip was dislocated, as he wrestled with him.[32:26] Then he said, “Let me go, for the dawn is breaking.” But Jacob replied, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.”[32:27] So he said to him, “What is your name?” He answered, “Jacob.”[32:28] Then he said, “Your name shall be no longer Jacob, but Israel^[ which means Struggler with God]; for you have struggled with God and with mortals and have won.”[32:29] Jacob asked him, “Tell me, I pray, your name.” He said,“Why do you ask my name?” So he blessed him there.[32:30] Jacob called the place Penuel^[ which means Face of God], for he said, “I have seen God face to face, and my life has been saved.”

[32:31] The sun rose as soon as he had passed beyond Penuel, and he limped because of his hip.[32:32] This is why to this day the Israelites do not eat the thigh muscle, which is at the socket of the hip, because he touched the socket of Jacob’s hip on the thigh muscle.

 [Genesis 33] 

##### Reconciliation #####

[33:1] When Jacob looked up, he saw Esau coming with four hundred men. So he divided the children between Leah and Rachel and the two slave-girls.[33:2] He put the slave-girls and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and her son Joseph in the rear.[33:3] Then Jacob himself went in front of them, and he bowed down to the ground seven times, as he drew near to his brother.[33:4] Esau ran to meet him, threw his arms about his neck, and kissed him, and they wept.

[33:5] When Esau looked up and saw the women and the children, he said, “Who are these with you?” Jacob answered, “The children whom God has so kindly given me.”[33:6] Then the slave-girls with their children came up and bowed down to the ground.[33:7] Leah and her children also came and bowed down, and afterward Joseph and Rachel came up and bowed down before Esau.

[33:8] Esau asked, “What do you mean by all this company which I met?” Jacob answered, “To win your friendship, my lord.”[33:9] Esau said, “I have enough, my brother; keep what you have.”[33:10] But Jacob replied, “No, if now I have won your favor, receive this present from me, because seeing your face when you welcomed me was like seeing the face of God.[33:11] Take, I beg of you, the gift that I bring to you, for God has been generous to me and I have enough.” So he urged Esau until he took it.

[33:12] Then Esau said, “Let us set out on our way, and let me travel with you.”[33:13] But Jacob replied, “My lord knows that the children are delicate, and I have flocks and herds with their young; if they are overdriven one day, all the flocks will die.[33:14] Let my lord, I beg of you, go on ahead of me, and I will proceed leisurely by stages according to the pace of the cattle which I am driving and of the children, until I come to my lord at Seir.”[33:15] Then Esau said, “Let me at least leave with you some of the people who are with me.” But Jacob replied, “What need is there? Let me only enjoy the favor of my lord.”[33:16] So Esau turned back that day on his way to Seir.

[33:17] But Jacob journeyed to Succoth, and built there a house for himself, and made huts for his cattle; therefore the name of the place is called Succoth^[ Huts].

##### Dinah and Shechem #####

[33:18] Now Jacob came in peace to the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan, when he came from Paddan-Aram, and encamped before the city.[33:19] He bought the piece of ground where he pitched his tent from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for four hundred shekels;[33:20] and he erected there an altar and called it El, God of Israel.

 [Genesis 34] 

[34:1] Dinah the daughter of Leah and Jacob, went out to visit the women of the region.[34:2] When Sheeham the son of Hamor the Hivite, the prince of the region, saw her, he took her and lay with her and violated her,[34:3] but his heart was drawn to Dinah the daughter of Jacob — he loved her and spoke endearingly to her.[34:4] Therefore Shechem said to his father Hamor, “Get me this girl for my wife.”

[34:5] When Jacob heard that Shecham had defiled Dinah his daughter, his sons were with his cattle in the field, so Jacob said nothing until they came home.[34:6] Meanwhile Hamor the father of Shechem went out to Jacob to speak with him and with his sons.

[34:7] The sons of Jacob came in from the field, and when they heard the news, the men were indignant and became very angry, because Shechem had committed a shameful crime in raping Jacob’s daughter: such a thing ought never to be done.[34:8] Hamor said to them, “My son Shechem has set his heart on your daughter. I beg you: give her to him as a wife[34:9] and intermarry with us. Give your daughters to us and take our daughters for yourselves.[34:10] Then you can settle with us, and the land will be open before you. Remain, go about, and settle down in it.”

[34:11] And Shechem said to Dinah’s father and to her brothers, “Let me find favor in your sight, and I will give you what you ask of me.[34:12] Demand of me an exceedingly large gift for yourselves and a dowry for the bride, and I shall give all you ask of me; only give me the girl for my wife.”

[34:13] Then the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father deceitfully, declaring, (because he had defiled their sister Dinah),[34:14] “We cannot do this. We cannot give our sister to someone who is uncircumcised, for that would be a disgrace to us.[34:15] Only on this condition will we make an alliance with you: if you will be as we are, in that every male of you be circumcised.[34:16] Then will we give our daughters to you and take your daughters to us and will live with you and we will become one people.[34:17] But if you will not listen to us and allow yourselves to be circumcised, then we will take Dinah and be gone.”

[34:18] Their proposal pleased Hamor and his son Shechem.[34:19] The young man (who was honored above all the house of his father) did not hesitate to do the thing demanded, because he was smitten with Jacob’s daughter.[34:20] Hamor and his son Shechem came to the gate of their city, and conversed with the men of their city, saying,[34:21] “These men are peaceably disposed toward us, let them remain in the land and go about in it; the land is broad enough for them on every side and in every direction; let us take their daughters to us for wives, and let us give them our daughters.[34:22] Only on this condition will these men consent to settle with us to become one people, namely, that every male among us be circumcised, as they are circumcised.[34:23] Shouldn’t their cattle and their goods and all their beasts be ours? Let us make an alliance with them so that they will live with us.”[34:24] Then all who went in and out of the gate of his city agreed with Hamor and Shechem. And every male was circumcised, all who went out of the gate of his city.

[34:25] On the third day when they were still in pain, two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, took swords and came upon the city unawares,[34:26] and put Hamor and his son Shechem to the sword, and took Dinah out of Shechem’s house and went away.[34:27] The other sons of Jacob came on the slain, and plundered the city, because they had defiled their sister.[34:28] They took their flocks and their herds and their donkeys and all that which was in the city and all that which was in the field.[34:29] All their wealth, and all their children and their wives, they took captive, and made all that was in the houses their prey.[34:30] Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought me into trouble, in that you have made me odious to the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and the Perizzites. Since I have only a few people, if they gather themselves together against me they will attack me — and I and my house will be destroyed.”[34:31] But they replied, “Should he have treated our sister like a whore?”

 [Genesis 35] 

##### Jacob goes to Bethel #####

[35:1] Then God said to Jacob, “Arise, go up to Bethel, and live there. Make an altar there to God, who appeared to you when you fled from your brother Esau.”[35:2] So Jacob said to his household, and to everyone who was with him, “Put away the foreign gods that are among you, and purify yourselves, and change your garments.[35:3] Let us arise and go up to Bethel. I will make there an altar to God, who answered me in the day of my distress, and was with me on the journey which I was making.”[35:4] So they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods which were in their possession, and the rings which were in their ears, and Jacob hid them under the oak which was by Shechem.[35:5] They set out on their journey, and a terror of God was upon the cities that were round about them, and they did not pursue after the sons of Jacob.[35:6] Then Jacob came to Luz, which is in the land of Canaan (that is, Bethel). He and all the people that were with him came to Bethel.[35:7] He built there an altar, and named the place El-Bethel^[ The God of the house of God]; because there God revealed himself to him, when he fled from the presence of his brother.[35:8] Then Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died, and was buried below Bethel under the oak. Therefore its name was called Allon-bacuth^[ Oak of Weeping].

[35:9] God appeared again to Jacob when he came from Paddanaram, and blessed him.[35:10] God said to him, “Now your name is Jacob: but your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel.” So he called his name Israel.[35:11] God said to him, “I am God Almighty; be fruitful and become numerous; a nation and a multitude of nations will come from you, and kings will descend from you;[35:12] and the land which I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you, and to your descendants after you.”[35:13] God went up from him at that place where he spoke with him.[35:14] Jacob set up at the place where God had spoken with him, a pillar of stone, and poured a drink-offering and oil on it.[35:15] Jacob called the name of the place where God spoke with him, Bethel.

[35:16] Then they set out from Bethel, and when they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel went into a hard and painful labor.[35:17] At the hardest, the midwife said to her, “Do not be afraid; for now you will have another son.”[35:18] And, as her life was departing (for she was dying), she called his name Ben-oni^[ Son of my Sorrow]; but his father called him Benjamin^[ Son of the right hand].[35:19] So Rachel died, and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem),[35:20] and Jacob set up a pillar on her grave: that is the Pillar of Rachel’s Grave, which stands until this day.

[35:21] Then Israel journeyed, and pitched his tent beyond Migdal-Eder^[ Tower of the Flock].[35:22] While Israel was living in that land, Reuben went and lay with his father’s concubine Bilhah and Israel heard of it.

Now the sons of Jacob were twelve:[35:23] The sons of Leah: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn, and Simeon, and Levi, and Judah, and Issachar, and Zebulun;[35:24] the sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin;[35:25] and the sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s slave-girl: Dan and Naphtali;[35:26] and the sons of Zilpah, Leah’s slave-girl: Gad and Asher (these are the sons of Jacob, that were born to him in Paddan-aram).

[35:27] Then Jacob came to Isaac his father, to Mamre, near Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had stayed.[35:28] The length of Isaac’s life was a one hundred and eighty years.[35:29] Isaac beathed his last, and was gathered to his father’s kin, old and satisfied with life; and Esau and Jacob his sons buried him.

 [Genesis 36] 

##### Genealogy #####

[36:1] Now these are the descendants of Esau (that is, Edom).[36:2] Esau took his wives from the Canaanites: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite,[36:3] and Basemath Ishmael’s daughter, sister of Nebaioth.[36:4] Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau; and Basemath bore Reuel;[36:5] and Oholibamah bore Jeush, and Jalam, and Korah. These were the sons of Esau that were born to him in the land of Canaan.

[36:6] Esau took his wives, and his sons, and his daughters, and all the members of his household and his cattle and all his beasts and all his possessionse which he had gathered in the land of Canaan and went into a land away from his brother Jacob.[36:7] For their possessions were too many for them to live together; and the land where they sojourned could not support them because of their cattle.[36:8] So Esau dwelt in Mount Seir (Esau is Edom).

[36:9] These are the descendants of Esau the father of the Edomites in Mount Seir:[36:10] these are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz the son of Esau’s wife Adah, Reuel the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.[36:11] The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, and Gatam, and Kenaz.[36:12] Timna was the concubine of Esau’s son Eliphaz; and she bore Amalek to him. These are the sons of Esau’s wife Adah.[36:13] These are the sons of Reuel: Nahath, and Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.[36:14] These were the sons of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Esau’s wife Zibeon she bore Jeush to Esau, and Jalam, and Korah.

[36:15] These are the chiefs descended from Esau. The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau: chief Teman, chief Omar, chief Zepho, chief Kenaz,[36:16] chief Korah, chief Gatam, chief Amalek. These are the chiefs descended from Eliphaz in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Adah.[36:17] These are the sons of Reuel, Esau’s son: chief Nahath, chief Zerah, chief Shammah, chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs descended from Reuel in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.[36:18] These are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau’s wife: chief Jeush, chief Jalam, chief Korah. These are the chiefs that came of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, Esau’s wife.[36:19] These are the sons of Esau (that is, Edom), and these are their chiefs.

[36:20] These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the original inhabitants of the land: Lotan and Shobal and Zibeon and Anah,[36:21] and Dishon and Ezer and Dishan. These are the chiefs that came of the Horites, the children of Seir in the land of Edom.[36:22] The sons of Lotan were Hori and Heman. Lotan’s sister was Timna.[36:23] These are the sons of Shobal: Alvan and Manahath and Ebal, Shepho and Onam.[36:24] These are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah; this is Anah who found the hot springs in the wilderness, as he fed the donkeys of his father Zibeon.[36:25] These are the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah.[36:26] These are the children of Dishon: Hemdan and Eshban and Ithran and Cheran.[36:27] These are the children of Ezer: Bilhan and Zaavan and Akan.[36:28] These are the children of Dishan: Uz and Aran.[36:29] These are the chiefs descended from the Horites: chief Lotan, chief Shobal, chief Zibeon, chief Anah,[36:30] chief Dishon, chief Ezer, chief Dishan. These are the chiefs that came of the Horites, according to their chiefs in the land of Seir.

[36:31] These are the kings that reigned in the land of Edom, before there reigned any king over the Israelites.[36:32] Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom; and the name of his city was Dinhabah.[36:33] Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead.[36:34] Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his stead.[36:35] Husham died, and Hadad the son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his stead. The name of his city was Avith.[36:36] Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his stead.[36:37] Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth by the River reigned in his stead.[36:38] Shaul died, and Baal-hanan the son of Achbor reigned in his stead.[36:39] Baal-hanan the son of Achbor died, and Hadar reigned in his stead: and the name of his city was Pau; and his wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Me-zahab.

[36:40] These are the names of the chiefs decended from Esau, according to their families, after their places, by their names: chief Timna, chief Alvah, chief Jetheth,[36:41] chief Oholibamah, chief Elah, chief Pinon,[36:42] chief Kenaz, chief Teman, chief Mibzar,[36:43] chief Magdiel, chief Iram. These are the chiefs of Edom, according to their settlements in the land they possessed. This was Esau, the father of the Edomites.

 [Genesis 37] 

##### Joseph sold into slavery #####

[37:1] Jacob made his home in the land of Canaan, where his father had lived as a resident foreigner.[37:2] Joseph at the age of seventeen was a shepherd with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, his father’s slave wives. He brought a bad report about them to their father.[37:3] Now Jacob loved his son Joseph, who was born in his old age; and he made him a long robe with sleeves.[37:4] When his brothers saw that their father loved Joseph more than all his other sons, they hated him and could not speak to him in a friendly manner.

[37:5] Joseph also had a dream and told it to his brothers, and they hated him still more.[37:6] This is what he said to them, “Hear, if you will, this dream which I have had;[37:7] for as we were binding sheaves in the field, my sheaf rose up and remained standing, while your sheaves came around and bowed down to my sheaf.”[37:8] His brothers said to him, “Do you think you will be king over us? And rule us?” So they hated him still more because of his dreams and his words.

[37:9] Then he had another dream and told it to his brothers, saying, “I have had another dream, and it seemed to me that the sun and the moon and eleven stars bowed down to me.”[37:10] But when he told it to his father and his brothers, his father reproved him and said, “What is this dream that you have dreamed? Am I and your mother and your brothers supposed to bow down to the earth before you?”[37:11] Therefore his brothers envied him; but his father kept the matter in mind.

[37:12] When his brothers went to pasture his father’s flocks in Shechem,[37:13] Israel said to Joseph, “Are not your brothers pasturing the flocks in Shechem? Come now, I will send you to them.” Joseph replied, “I am ready.”[37:14] So his father said to him, “Go, see whether all goes well with your brothers and with the flock, and bring me back word.” So he sent him out from the valley of Hebron, and he came to Shechem.[37:15] There a man found him, as he was wandering in the field, and the man asked him, “What are you seeking?”[37:16] He said, “I am looking for my brothers; tell me, please, where they are pasturing the flock.”[37:17] The man said, “They have gone away, for I heard them say, ‘Let us go to Dothan.’” So Joseph went after his brothers and found them in Dothan.

[37:18] When they saw him in the distance, before he came to them, they conspired against him to kill him.[37:19] They said one to another, “See, here comes that master-dreamer.[37:20] Come on, let us kill him, and throw him into one of the pits, and then we will say, ‘A fierce beast has devoured him’; and we shall see what will become of his dreams!”[37:21] Rueben, however, when he heard it, saved him from their hands by saying, “Let us not take his life.”[37:22] Reuben also said to them, “Do not shed blood; throw him into this pit, that is in the wilderness; but do not harm him,” He planned to save him from their hands in order to restore him to his father.[37:23] Nevertheless, when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of his long robe, the robe with sleeves;[37:24] and they took him and threw him into the pit. But the pit was empty, there being no water in it.

[37:25] Then they sat down to eat bread, and when they looked up they saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead, and their camels were loaded with spices, balm and myrrh on their way to carry it down to Egypt.[37:26] Judah said to his brothers, “What do we gain if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?[37:27] Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites, and let us do him no violence, for he is our brother, our own flesh and blood.” So his brothers listened to him;[37:28] and when the Midianite merchants passed by, pulled Joseph up from the pit and sold him for twenty pieces of silver to the Ishmaelites, who brought him to Egypt.

[37:29] When Reuben returned to the pit and found Joseph gone, he tore his clothes in sorrow.[37:30] He went back to his brothers and said, “The boy is gone! What am I going to do?”

[37:31] Then his brothers took Joseph’s robe, killed a he-goat, dipped the long-sleeved robe in the blood,[37:32] tore it and sent it to their father, saying, “We found this; see whether it is your son’s robe or not.”[37:33] He recognized it and said, “It is my son’s robe! A wild beast has devoured him! Joseph without doubt is torn in pieces.”[37:34] Then Jacob tore his clothes, put sackcloth about his waist, and mourned for his son many days.[37:35] All his sons and his daughters tried to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted, saying, “I shall go down to the grave mourning for my son.” So Joseph’s father wept for him.

[37:36] Meanwhile, the Midianites had sold Joseph in Egypt to one of Pharaoh’s court officials, Potiphar, the captain of the guard.

 [Genesis 38] 

##### Judah and Tamar #####

[38:1] About that time Judah left his kinsmen, and settled near a certain Adullamite, whose name was Hirah.[38:2] Judah saw there a daughter of a Canaanite whose name was Shua, and he married her. He lay with her,[38:3] and she conceived, and bore a son, and he named him Er.[38:4] Then she conceived again, and bore a son and named him Onan.[38:5] She bore still another son, and named him Shelah: and it was at Chezib that she bore him.

[38:6] Now Judah found a wife for Er his eldest son, and her name was Tamar.[38:7] But Er, Judah’s eldest son, was wicked in the sight of the LORD, and the LORD  took his life.[38:8] Then Judah said to Onan, “Go and lie with your brother’s wife, and perform the duty of a husband’s brother to her, and raise up offspring for your brother.”[38:9] But Onan knew that the child would not be his; so whenever he lay with his brother’s wife, he spilled his semen on the ground, in order not to raise up offspring for his brother.[38:10] What he did was evil in the sight of the LORD : therefore he took his life also.

[38:11] Then said Judah to Tamar his daughter-in-law, “Remain a widow in your father’s house, until Shelah my son is grown up”; for he said to himself, “I will not let him marry her, he must not die like his brothers.” So Tamar went and lived in her father’s house.

[38:12] After many days had passed, Shua’s daughter, the wife of Judah, died. When Judah had finished mourning, he went up to see about his sheep-shearers at Timnah, with his friend Hirah the Adullamite.[38:13] Someone told Tamar, saying, “Behold, your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.”[38:14] She took off the garments of her widowhood, and covered herself with her veil. She sat, veiled, in the gate of Enaim, which is by the way to Timnah; for she saw that Shelah had grown up without her being given to him as wife.[38:15] When Judah saw her, he thought her to be a prostitute; because she had veiled her face.[38:16] So he turned aside to her by the roadside, and said, “Permit me, I pray you, to lie with you.” For he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law. And she said, “What will you give me to lie with me?”[38:17] He said, “I will send you a young goat from the flock.” She said, “Will you give me a pledge, until you send it?”[38:18] He said, “What pledge should I give you?” And she said, “Your seal-ring and your chain and your staff that is in your hand.” So he gave them to her, and lay with her, and she became pregnant.[38:19] And she got up, and went away, and took off her veil, and put on the garments of her widowhood.

[38:20] Now when Judah sent the young goat by the hand of his friend the Adullamite, to receive the pledge from the woman’s hand, he could not find her.[38:21] He asked the men of her place, saying, “Where is the sacred prostitute, who was at Enaim by the wayside?” They replied, “There has been no sacred prostitute here.”[38:22] So he returned to Judah, and said, “I have not found her; and the men of the place said, ‘There has been no sacred prostitute here.’”[38:23] Judah said, “Let her keep the pledge, otherwise we will be put to shame. I have sent this goat, and you have not found her.”

[38:24] Now after about three months, Judah was told, “Tamar your daughter-in-law has been acting like a whore and is pregnant.” Judah said, “Bring her forth and let her be burnt.”[38:25] But when she was brought forth, she sent to her father-in-law, saying, “By the man to whom these things belong, I am with child.” She also said, “Look at them and see if you know whose these are, the seal-ring and the chain and the staff.”[38:26] When Judah recognized them, he said, “She is more in the right than I, because I did not give her to Shelah my son.” But he did not lie with her again.

[38:27] When her time came to give birth, it was found that twins were in her womb.[38:28] While she was in labor, one put out a hand and the midwife took and bound on his hand a bright red thread, saying, “This one came out first.”[38:29] But he drew back his hand, and his brother came out, and she said, “What a breach you have made for yourself!” Therefore he was named Perez^[ Breach].[38:30] Afterward his brother came out, who had the bright red thread on his hand; therefore he was named Zerah^[ Red].

 [Genesis 39] 

##### Joseph in Egypt #####

[39:1] Joseph was taken down to Egypt, and Potiphar, one of Pharaoh’s officers, the captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.

[39:2] Now the LORD  was with Joseph, so that he prospered; and he remained in the house of his master the Egyptian.[39:3] When his master saw that the LORD  was with him and made everything that he undertook prosper,[39:4] Joseph won his confidence and became his personal attendant. He also made him overseer of his household and placed all that he had in his care.[39:5] From the time that he made him overseer in his house and over all that he had, the LORD  blessed the Egyptian’s household for Joseph’s sake, and the blessing of the LORD  was upon all that he had in the house and in the field.[39:6] Leaving all that he had in Joseph’s charge, he knew nothing about his affairs except about the food which he ate. Also Joseph was handsome and attractive.

[39:7] After these honors had come to Joseph, his master’s wife directed her glances toward him and tried to tempt him.[39:8] But he refused, saying to her, “See, my master knows nothing about what I do in the house, and he has put all that he has in my charge.[39:9] No one has greater authority in this house than I, and he has kept back nothing from me but you, because you are his wife. How then can I do this great wrong and sin against God?”[39:10] Day after day she tempted Joseph, but he did not listen to her nor accept her advances.[39:11] One day, however, when he went into the house to do his work and when none of the men of the household were at home,[39:12] she caught hold of his garment and tried to seduce him; but he left his garment in her hand and fled out of the house.

[39:13] When she saw that he had left his garment in her hand and had fled,[39:14] she called to her household servants and said to them,“See, the master has brought a Hebrew in to insult us. He came to me to rape me, and I screamed loudly;[39:15] and when he heard me scream, he left his garment with me and ran out of the house.”[39:16] She kept his garment by her until his master came home;[39:17] then she told him the same story, saying, “The Hebrew slave whom you have brought to us came to me to insult me;[39:18] and when I screamed he left his garment with me and fled.”

[39:19] When Joseph’s master heard the statements which his wife made to him, his anger was aroused;[39:20] and he took Joseph and put him into the prison, in the place where the king’s prisoners were confined. So he was left there in prison.[39:21] But the LORD  was with Joseph and showed kindness to him and enabled him to win the favor of the keeper of the prison,[39:22] so that he placed all the prisoners in Joseph’s charge and made him responsible for whatever they did there.[39:23] The keeper did not have to concern himself about anything Joseph was responsible for, because the LORD  was with him and gave him success in everything he did.

 [Genesis 40] 

##### The Two Dreams #####

[40:1] Some time after these things the cupbearer of the king of Egypt and his baker offended their master the king of Egypt,[40:2] so that Pharaoh was angry with these two officers and imprisoned them in the house of the captain of the guard, in the same prison where Joseph was confined.[40:3] The captain of the guard assigned Joseph to them, and he waited on them;[40:4] and they remained in confinement for some time.

[40:5] Meanwhile the king of Egypt’s cupbearer and baker, who were confined in the prison, both had dreams the same night, each with a particular meaning.[40:6] When Joseph came in to them in the morning, he saw plainly that they were sad.[40:7] So he asked Pharaoh’s officers, “Why do you look so sad today?”[40:8] They answered. “We have had a dream and there is no one who can interpret it.” Then Joseph said to them, “Do not the interpretations of dreams belong to God? Tell them to me.”

[40:9] Then the chief cupbearer told his dream to Joseph and said to him, “In my dream I saw a vine before me,[40:10] and on the vine were three branches, and as if budding it put out blossoms and its clusters brought forth ripe grapes.[40:11] Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes and pressed them into his cup and gave the cup to Pharaoh.”

[40:12] Then Joseph said to him, “This is its interpretation: the three branches are three days;[40:13] within three days Pharaoh will release you from prison and restore you to your office, and you will give Pharaoh’s cup into his hand as you used to do when you were his cupbearer.[40:14] But when all goes well with you, remember me, show kindness to me and speak in my behalf to Pharaoh and bring me out of this house;[40:15] for I was unjustly stolen from the land of the Hebrews, and here also I have done nothing that they should put me in the dungeon.”

[40:16] When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was favorable, he said to Joseph, “I also saw something in my dream: there were three baskets of white bread on my head,[40:17] and in the uppermost basket there were all kinds of baked food for Pharaoh, and the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head.”[40:18] Joseph answered, “This is its interpretation: the three baskets are three days;[40:19] within three days Pharaoh will take off your head and hang you on a tree, and the birds shall eat your flesh.”

[40:20] Now on the third day, which was Pharaoh’s birthday, he made a feast for all his officials. Then he released the chief cupbearer and the chief baker.[40:21] He restored the chief butler to his office, so that he again gave the cup into Pharaoh’s hand,[40:22] but the chief baker he hanged, as Joseph had interpreted to them.[40:23] Yet the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph, but forgot him.

 [Genesis 41] 

##### Pharaoh’s Dream #####

[41:1] Two years later Pharaoh had a dream: as he stood by the Nile,[41:2] he saw coming up from the Nile seven cows, good-looking and fat, and they had been feeding in the river grass.[41:3] Then seven other cows came up after them out of the Nile, bad-looking and lean, and they stood by the other cows on the bank of the Nile.[41:4] The bad-looking cows ate up the seven good-looking, fat cows. Then Pharaoh awoke.

[41:5] Afterward he slept and had a second dream and saw seven ears, plump and good, growing up on one stalk.[41:6] Also seven ears, thin and blasted by the east wind, sprang up after them.[41:7] The thin ears swallowed up the seven plump, full ears. Then Pharaoh awoke, and realized that it was a dream.

[41:8] In the morning Pharaoh’s mind was disturbed; so he sent and called all the magicians and wise men of Egypt and told them his dreams, but no one could interpret them to him.

[41:9] Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, “I now must remind you of my offenses:[41:10] Pharaoh was very angry with his servants and imprisoned me and the chief baker in the house of the captain of the guard.[41:11] We both had dreams the same night, each with a special meaning.[41:12] There was also with us a young Hebrew, a slave of the captain of the guard; and we told him and he interpreted our dreams to us, to each of us according to his dream.[41:13] Our dreams came true exactly as he interpreted them to us: I was restored to my office, but the other man was hanged.”

[41:14] Then Pharaoh sent for Joseph, and they brought him hastily out of the dungeon; and he shaved his face and changed his clothes and came to Pharaoh.[41:15] Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I have had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it. Now I have heard it said of you that when you hear a dream you can interpret it.”[41:16] Joseph answered Pharaoh, “Not I; God only can give Pharaoh a satisfactory answer.”

[41:17] Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “In my dream as I stood on the bank of the Nile,[41:18] I saw seven cows, fat and good-looking, which had been feeding in the river grass.[41:19] There came up after them seven more cows, thin, and bad-looking and lean, worse than I ever saw in all the land of Egypt;[41:20] and the lean and bad-looking cows ate up the first seven fat cows;[41:21] and when they had eaten them up, one could not tell that they had eaten them, for they were still as bad-looking as at the beginning. Then I awoke.[41:22] Again I dreamed and saw seven ears, plump and good, grow up on one stalk;[41:23] then seven ears, withered, thin, blasted with the east wind, sprang up after them;[41:24] and the thin ears swallowed up the seven good ears. I have told the dream to the magicians, but there is no one who can interpret it to me.”

[41:25] Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, “Pharaoh’s two dreams signify the same thing; God has made known to Pharaoh what he is about to do.[41:26] The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good ears are seven years. It is one dream.[41:27] The seven lean and ugly cows that came up after them are also seven years, and the seven empty ears blasted with the east wind represent seven years of famine.[41:28] That is why I said to Pharaoh, ‘God has shown to Pharaoh what he is about to do.’[41:29] Seven years of great plenty throughout the land of Egypt are coming,[41:30] and they will be followed by seven years of famine, so that all the plenty will be forgotten in the land of Egypt. The famine will consume all that the land produces;[41:31] and plenty will not be known in the land because of that famine which follows, for it will be very severe.

[41:32] “The dream came twice to Pharaoh to indicate that its fulfilment is assured and that God will soon make it come true.[41:33] Now therefore let Pharaoh select a man who is discreet and wise and place him in control of the land of Egypt.[41:34] Pharaoh should take action and appoint overseers over the land and collect one-fifth of all the produce of Egypt in the seven plenteous years.[41:35] Let them gather all the food of these good years that come and store the grain under the authority of Pharaoh, and let them hold it for food in the cities.[41:36] The food will furnish a supply for the land during the seven years of famine which will be in the land of Egypt, so that the people of the land will not perish because of the famine.”

[41:37] The plan pleased Pharaoh and all his officials;[41:38] and Pharaoh said to his officials, “Can we find one like this, a man in whom is the spirit of God?”[41:39] So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has shown you all this, there is no one so discreet and wise as you.[41:40] You will be at the head of my dominion, and all my people shall be ruled as you command, only on the throne I will be superior to you.”

[41:41] So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “See, I have appointed you over all the land of Egypt.”[41:42] Pharaoh took off his signet ring from his finger and put it upon Joseph’s finger and clothed him in garments of fine linen and put a golden collar about his neck.[41:43] He also made him ride in the second-best chariot which he had; and they cried before him, “Attention!” So he placed him over all the land of Egypt.

[41:44] Pharaoh also said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, but without your consent no one may lift up hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.”[41:45] Pharaoh named Joseph Zaphenath-paneah and gave him as a wife Asenath the daughter of Potiphera, priest of On. Josephs’s authority was over all Egypt,[41:46] and so at the age of thirty Joseph was commissioned by Pharaoh, king of Egypt and went out as the head of the land of Egypt.

[41:47] In the seven plenteous years there were bountiful harvests,[41:48] and Joseph gathered up all the food of the seven plenteous years, which were in the land of Egypt, and stored the food in the cities, putting in each city the products of the fields about it.[41:49] Joseph stored up grain as the sand of the sea, in great quantities, until he ceased to keep account, because it could not be measured.

[41:50] Two sons were born to Joseph and Asenath before the year of famine came.[41:51] Joseph named the eldest Manasseh^[ Making Forget]; for he said, “God has made me forget all my toil and all my father’s household.”[41:52] He named the second son Ephraim^[ Fruitful]; for he said, “God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.”

[41:53] When the seven years of plenty which had been in the land of Egypt were over,[41:54] the seven years of famine began, as Joseph had said; and there was famine in all lands, but throughout the land of Egypt there was food,[41:55] for when all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread, and Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph and do what he tells you.”[41:56] So when the famine was universal throughout the earth, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold food to the Egyptians: but the famine was severe in the land of Egypt.[41:57] The peoples of all lands came to Joseph in Egypt to buy grain, for the famine was severe throughout the world.

 [Genesis 42] 

##### Joseph’s brothers come to Egypt #####

[42:1] Jacob learned that there was grain for sale in Egypt, and he said to his sons, “Why do you stand looking at each other?[42:2] I have heard that there is grain for sale in Egypt; go down there and buy for us, so that we may live and not die.”[42:3] So Joseph’s ten brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.[42:4] But Jacob did not send Benjamin, Joseph’s own brother, with his brothers; for he feared that some harm might come to him.[42:5] So the sons of Jacob went among others to buy grain, for the famine was in the land of Canaan.

[42:6] Now Joseph was the governor over the land; it was he who sold to all the people of the land. Therefore Joseph’s brothers came and bowed before him with their faces to the earth.[42:7] When Joseph saw his brothers he knew them, but he acted as a stranger toward them and spoke harshly to them and said, “Where do you come from?” They said, “From the land of Canaan to buy food.”[42:8] So Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not know him.

[42:9] Joseph also remembered the dreams which he had dreamed about them and said to them, “You spies! You have come to find out the weaknesses of the land.”[42:10] But they said to him, “No my lord; your servants have come to buy food.[42:11] We are all sons of one man; we are honest men; your servants are not spies.”[42:12] But he said to them, “No, you have come to see the weaknesses of the land.”[42:13] They replied, “We, your servants, are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan; the youngest is today with our father, and one is no more.”[42:14] Joseph said to them, “It is just as I said to you, you are spies.[42:15] By this you shall be tested: as sure as Pharaoh lives you shall not go away unless your youngest brother comes here.[42:16] Send one of you, and let him bring your brother, while you remain in prison, that it may be proved whether you are telling the truth or not.
