|    wondrous things out of your law.
|  [119:19] But a guest am I on the earth:
|    hide not your commandments from me.
|  [119:20] My heart is crushed with longing
|    for your ordinances, at all times.
|  [119:21] You rebuke the proud, the accursed,
|    who wander from your commandments.
|  [119:22] Roll away from me scorn and contempt,
|    for I have observed your charges.
|  [119:23] Though princes sit plotting against me,
|    your servant will muse on your statutes.
|  [119:24] Your charges are my delight,
|    they are my counsellors.

|  [119:25] I lie grovelling in the dust;
|    revive me, as you have promised.
|  [119:26] I told of my ways, you made answer;
|    teach me your statutes.
|  [119:27] Grant me insight into your precepts,
|    and I will muse on your wonders.
|  [119:28] I am overcome with sorrow;
|    raise me up, as you have promised.
|  [119:29] Put the way of falsehood from me,
|    and graciously grant me your law.
|  [119:30] I have chosen the way of fidelity,
|    your ordinances I long for.
|  [119:31] I hold fast to your charges:
|    O put me not, LORD, to shame.
|  [119:32] I will run in the way of your commandments,
|    for you give me room of heart.

|  [119:33] Teach me, O LORD, the way of your statutes,
|    and I will keep it to the end,
|  [119:34] instruct me to keep your law,
|    and I will observe it with all my heart.
|  [119:35] Guide me in the path of your commandments,
|    for therein do I delight.
|  [119:36] Incline my heart to your charges,
|    and not to greed of gain.
|  [119:37] Turn away my eyes from vain sights,
|    revive me by your word.
|  [119:38] Confirm to your servant the promise
|    which is given to those who fear you.
|  [119:39] Remove the reproach which I dread,
|    because your judgments are good.
|  [119:40] Behold, I long for your precepts.
|    Quicken me in your righteousness.

|  [119:41] Visit me, LORD, with your love
|    and salvation, as you have promised.
|  [119:42] So shall I answer my slanderers,
|    for my trust is in your word.
|  [119:43] Snatch not from my mouth the word of truth,
|    for in your judgments I hope.
|  [119:44] I will keep your law continually,
|    for ever and evermore.
|  [119:45] So shall I walk in wide spaces,
|    for I give my mind to your precepts.
|  [119:46] I will speak of your charge before kings,
|    and will not be ashamed thereof.
|  [119:47] Your commandments are my delight,
|    I love them exceedingly.
|  [119:48] I will lift up my hands to your commandments,
|    and muse upon your statutes.

|  [119:49] Remember your word to your servant,
|    on which you have made me to hope.
|  [119:50] This is my comfort in trouble,
|    that your word gives life to me.
|  [119:51] The arrogant utterly scorn me,
|    but I have not declined from your law.
|  [119:52] When I think of your judgments of old,
|    O LORD, I take to me comfort.
|  [119:53] I am seized with glowing anger
|    at the wicked who forsake your law.
|  [119:54] Your statutes have been to me songs
|    in the house of my pilgrimage.
|  [119:55] I remember your name in the night,
|    O LORD  and observe your law.
|  [119:56] My lot has been this,
|    that I have kept your precepts.

|  [119:57] My portion are you, O LORD :
|    I have promised to keep your words.
|  [119:58] I entreat you with all my heart;
|    grant me your promised favor.
|  [119:59] I have thought upon my ways,
|    and turned my feet to your charges.
|  [119:60] I hasted and tarried not
|    to give heed to your commandments.
|  [119:61] Though the godless have wound their cords round me,
|    I have not forgotten your law.
|  [119:62] At midnight I rise to praise you
|    because of your righteous judgments.
|  [119:63] With all those who fear you I company,
|    aid with those who observe your precepts.
|  [119:64] The earth, LORD, is full of your kindness;
|    teach me your Statutes.

|  [119:65] Well have you dealt with your servant,
|    as you have promised, O LORD .
|  [119:66] Teach me discretion and knowledge,
|    for I have believed your commandments.
|  [119:67] Till trouble came I was a wanderer,
|    but now I observe your word.
|  [119:68] You are good and do good;
|    teach me your statutes.
|  [119:69] The proud have forged lies against me,
|    but I keep your precepts with all my heart.
|  [119:70] Their heart is gross like fat,
|    but I delight in your law.
|  [119:71] It was good for me to be humbled,
|    that I should learn your statutes.
|  [119:72] The law of your mouth is better to me
|    than thousands of pieces of silver and gold.

|  [119:73] Your hands have made me and fashioned me;
|    make me wise to learn your commandments.
|  [119:74] Those who fear you shall see me with joy,
|    for in your word have I hoped.
|  [119:75] I know, O LORD, that your judgments are right,
|    and in faithfulness you have afflicted me.
|  [119:76] Let your love be a comfort to me,
|    for so have you promised your servant.
|  [119:77] Visit me with your quickening pity,
|    for your law is my delight.
|  [119:78] Put the proud to shame, who have wronged me falsely:
|    I will muse on your precepts.
|  [119:79] Let those turn to me who fear you,
|    that they may learn your charges.
|  [119:80] Let my heart be sound in your statutes,
|    that I may not be put to shame.

|  [119:81] My long for you to rescue me,
|    I put my hope in your word.
|  [119:82] My eyes pine away for your promise:
|    saying, “When will you comfort me?”
|  [119:83] Though shrivelled like wine-skin in smoke,
|    your statutes I have not forgotten.
|  [119:84] How few are the days of your servant!
|    When will you judge those who harass me?
|  [119:85] Proud people have dug for me pits
|    people who do not conform to your law.
|  [119:86] All your commandments are trusty.
|    With falsehood they harass me: help me.
|  [119:87] They had nearly made an end of me,
|    yet I did not forget your precepts.
|  [119:88] Spare me in your kindness,
|    and I will observe the charge of your mouth.

|  [119:89] Forever, O LORD, is your word
|    fixed firmly in the heavens.
|  [119:90] Your truth endures age after age;
|    it is established on earth, and it stands.
|  [119:91] By your appointment they stand this day,
|    for all are your servants.
|  [119:92] Had not your law been my joy,
|    in my misery then had I perished.
|  [119:93] I will never forget your precepts,
|    for through them you have put life in me.
|  [119:94] I am yours, O save me,
|    for I give my mind to your precepts.
|  [119:95] The wicked lay wait to destroy me,
|    but I give heed to your charge.
|  [119:96] I have seen a limit to all things:
|    but your commandment is spacious exceedingly.

|  [119:97] O how I love your law!
|    All the day long I muse on it.
|  [119:98] Your commandment makes me wiser than my enemies:
|    for it is mine forever.
|  [119:99] I am prudent above all my teachers,
|    for your charges are my meditation.
|  [119:100] I have insight more than the aged,
|    because I observe your precepts.
|  [119:101] I refrain my foot from all wicked ways,
|    that I may keep your word.
|  [119:102] I turn not aside from your judgments,
|    for you yourself are my teacher.
|  [119:103] How sweet are your words to my taste,
|    sweeter than honey to my mouth!
|  [119:104] Insight I win through your precepts,
|    therefore every false way I hate.

|  [119:105] Your word is a lamp to my feet,
|    and a light to my path.
|  [119:106] I have sworn an oath, and will keep it,
|    to observe your righteous judgments.
|  [119:107] I am afflicted sorely:
|    revive me, O LORD, as you said.
|  [119:108] Accept, LORD, my willing praise,
|    and teach me your judgments.
|  [119:109] My life is in ceaseless peril;
|    but I do not forget your law.
|  [119:110] The wicked set traps for me,
|    yet I do not stray from your precepts.
|  [119:111] In your charges are my everlasting inheritance,
|    they are the joy of my heart.
|  [119:112] I am resolved to perform your statutes
|    forever, to the utmost.

|  [119:113] I hate people of divided heart,
|    but your law do I love.
|  [119:114] You are my shelter and shield:
|    in your word do I hope.
|  [119:115] Begone, you wicked people,
|    I will keep the commands of my God.
|  [119:116] Uphold me and spare me, as you have promised:
|    O disappoint me not.
|  [119:117] Hold me up, and I shall be saved:
|    and your statutes shall be my unceasing delight.
|  [119:118] All who swerve from your statutes you spurn:
|    their cunning is in vain.
|  [119:119] All the wicked of earth you count as dross,
|    therefore I love your charges.
|  [119:120] My flesh, for fear of you, shudders,
|    and I stand in awe of your judgments.

|  [119:121] Justice and right have I practised,
|    do not leave me to my oppressors.
|  [119:122] Be your servant’s surety for good,
|    let not the proud oppress me.
|  [119:123] My eyes pine for your salvation,
|    and for your righteous promise.
|  [119:124] Deal in your love with your servant,
|    and teach me your statutes.
|  [119:125] Your servant am I; instruct me,
|    that I may know your charges.
|  [119:126] It is time for the LORD  to act:
|    they have violated your law.
|  [119:127] Therefore I love your commandments
|    above gold, above fine gold.
|  [119:128] So by all your precepts I guide me,
|    and every false way I hate.

|  [119:129] Your decrees are wonderful,
|    gladly I keep them.
|  [119:130] When your word is unfolded, light breaks;
|    it imparts to the simple wisdom.
|  [119:131] With open mouth I pant
|    with longing for your commandments.
|  [119:132] Turn to me with your favor,
|    as is just to those who love you.
|  [119:133] Steady my steps by your word,
|    so that sin have no power over me.
|  [119:134] Set me free from those who oppress me,
|    and I shall observe your precepts.
|  [119:135] Shine with your face on your servant,
|    and teach me your statutes.
|  [119:136] My eyes run down with rills of water,
|    because your law is not kept.

|  [119:137] Righteous are you, O LORD,
|    and right are your ordinances.
|  [119:138] The laws you has ordered are just,
|    and trusty exceedingly.
|  [119:139] My jealousy has undone me,
|    that my foes have forgotten your words.
|  [119:140] Your word has been tested well;
|    and your servant loves it.
|  [119:141] I am little and held in contempt,
|    but your precepts I have not forgotten.
|  [119:142] Just is your justice forever,
|    and trusty is your law.
|  [119:143] Stress and strain are upon me,
|    but your commandments are my delight.
|  [119:144] Right are your charges forever,
|    instruct me that I may live.

|  [119:145] With my whole heart I cry; O answer me.
|    I would keep your statutes, O LORD .
|  [119:146] I cry to you: O save me,
|    and I will observe your charges.
|  [119:147] Ere the dawn I cry for your help:
|    in your word do I hope.
|  [119:148] Awake I meet the night-watches,
|    to muse upon your sayings.
|  [119:149] Hear my voice in your kindness:
|    O LORD, by your judgments revive me.
|  [119:150] Near me are wicked tormentors,
|    who are far from thoughts of your law;
|  [119:151] but near, too, are you, O LORD,
|    and all your commandments are trusty.
|  [119:152] Long have I known from your charges
|    that you have founded them for all time.

|  [119:153] Look on my misery, and rescue me;
|    for I do not forget your law.
|  [119:154] Defend my cause and redeem me:
|    revive me, as you have promised.
|  [119:155] Salvation is far from the wicked,
|    for their mind is not in your statutes.
|  [119:156] Great is your pity, O LORD :
|    Revive me, as you have ordained.
|  [119:157] My foes and tormentors are many,
|    but I have not declined from your charges.
|  [119:158] I behold the traitors with loathing,
|    for they do not observe your word.
|  [119:159] Behold how I love your precepts:
|    revive me, O LORD !, in your kindness.
|  [119:160] The sum of your word is truth,
|    all your laws are just and eternal.

|  [119:161] Princes have harassed me wantonly:
|    but my heart stands in awe of your word.
|  [119:162] Over your word I rejoice
|    as one who finds great spoil.
|  [119:163] Falsehood I hate and abhor,
|    but your law do I love.
|  [119:164] Seven times a day do I praise you
|    because of your righteous judgments.
|  [119:165] Right well do they fare who love your law:
|    they go on their way without stumbling.
|  [119:166] I hope for your salvation;
|    O LORD  I do your commandments.
|  [119:167] I observe your charges:
|    I love them greatly.
|  [119:168] I observe your precepts and charges:
|    all my ways are before you.

|  [119:169] Let my cry come before you, O LORD :
|    give me insight, as you have promised.
|  [119:170] Let my prayer enter into your presence:
|    deliver me, as you have said.
|  [119:171] My lips shall be fountains of praise,
|    that you teach me your statutes.
|  [119:172] My tongue shall sing of your word,
|    for all your commandments are right.
|  [119:173] Let your hand be ready to help me,
|    for your precepts have been my choice.
|  [119:174] I long, LORD, for your salvation,
|    and your law is my delight.
|  [119:175] Revive me that I may praise you,
|    and let your precepts help me.
|  [119:176] I have strayed like a wandering sheep
|    seek your servant, because
|    I do not forget your commandments.

 [Psalms 120] 

##### Psalm 120 – Prayer for Deliverance from Slander and Treachery #####

A song of ascents.

|  [120:1] In distress I cried to the LORD,
|    and he answered me.
|  [120:2] “Deliver me, LORD,
|    from the lip that is false
|    and the tongue that is crafty.”

|  [120:3] What shall he give to you,
|    you tongue that is crafty?
|  What yet shall he give to you?
|  [120:4] Arrows of warrior, sharpened,
|    with glowing broom coals together.

|  [120:5] Woe is me that I sojourn in Meshech,
|    that I live by the tents of Kedar.
|  [120:6] Already too long have I dwelt
|    among those who hate peace.
|  [120:7] I am for peace:
|    but when I speak of it,
|    they are for war.

 [Psalms 121] 

##### Psalm 121 – The Lord Our Protector #####

##### A song of ascents #####

|  [121:1] I will lift up my eyes to the mountains.
|    O whence shall help for me come?
|  [121:2] From the LORD  comes help to me
|    the creator of heaven and earth.

|  [121:3] Your foot he will not let totter:
|    he who guards you will not sleep.
|  [121:4] The guardian of Israel
|    will neither slumber nor sleep.

|  [121:5] The LORD  is he who guards you
|    your shelter upon your right hand.
|  [121:6] The sun by day shall not strike you,
|    nor the moon by night.

|  [121:7] From all evil the LORD  will guard you,
|    he will guard your life.
|  [121:8] The LORD  will guard your going and coming
|    from now and for evermore.

 [Psalms 122] 

##### Psalm 122 – The Joy and the Prayer of the Pilgrims #####

A song of ascents. Of David.

|  [122:1] I was glad when they said to me,
|    “We will go to the house of the LORD .”
|  [122:2] Now we are standing,
|    within your gates, O Jerusalem.

|  [122:3] O Jerusalem, built close-packed,
|    like a city without breach or gap,
|  [122:4] to you do the tribes come,
|    the tribes of the LORD,
|  as the law has ordained for Israel,
|    there to give thanks to the LORD .
|  [122:5] There once stood thrones of justice
|    even thrones of the household of David.

|  [122:6] Pray that all may be well with Jerusalem,
|    and well with those who love you,
|  [122:7] well within your ramparts,
|    and well within your palaces.

|  [122:8] For the sake of my brethren and friends,
|    I will wish you now prosperity:
|  [122:9] for the sake of the house of the LORD
|     our God, I will seek your good.

 [Psalms 123] 

##### Psalm 123 – A Prayer for Mercy #####

A song of ascents.

|  [123:1] I Lift up my eyes to you,
|    who are throned in the heavens.
|  [123:2] As the eyes of a servant
|    turn to the hand of his master,
|  or the eyes of a maid
|    to the hand of her mistress,
|  so do our eyes turn
|    to the LORD  our God,
|  until he is gracious to us.

|  [123:3] Be gracious, be gracious to us, LORD .
|    Scorn enough, and more, have we borne
|  [123:4] More than enough have we borne
|    of derision from those at their ease,
|    of scorn from those who are haughty.

 [Psalms 124] 

##### Psalm 124 – A Magnificent Deliverance #####

A song of ascents. Of David.

|  [124:1] “Had it not been the LORD  who was for us”
|    let Israel say
|  [124:2] “Had it not been the LORD  who was for us
|  when enemies rose against us,
|  [124:3] then alive they’d have swallowed us up,
|    when their anger was kindled against us.
|  [124:4] Then the waters would’ve swept us away,
|    and the torrent passed over us clean:
|  [124:5] then most sure would’ve passed over us clean
|    the wild seething waters.”

|  [124:6] Blest be the LORD  who has given us not
|    to be torn by their teeth.
|  [124:7] We are like a bird just escaped
|    from the snare of the fowler.

|  The snare is broken,
|    and we are escaped.
|  [124:8] Our help is the name of the LORD,
|    the Creator of heaven and earth.

 [Psalms 125] 

##### Psalm 125 – A Sure Defence #####

A song of ascents.

|  [125:1] Those who trust in the LORD
|     are like Mount Zion,
|  that cannot be moved,
|    but abides forever.
|  [125:2] Round Jerusalem are the mountains,
|    and the LORD  is round his people
|    from now and for evermore.

|  [125:3] For he will not suffer
|    the sceptre of wrong
|  to rest on the land
|    allotted to the righteous;
|  else the righteous might put forth
|    their own hand to evil.

|  [125:4] Do good, O LORD,
|    to the good,
|    and to the true-hearted.

|  [125:5] But those who swerve
|    into crooked ways
|  will the LORD  lead away
|    with the workers of evil.

|      Peace be upon Israel.

 [Psalms 126] 

##### Psalm 126 – Sowing in Tears #####

A song of ascents.

|  [126:1] When the LORD  turned the fortunes of Zion,
|    we were like dreamers.
|  [126:2] Then was our mouth filled with laughter,
|    our tongue with glad shouts;
|  then among the nations they said,
|    “The LORD  has dealt greatly with them.”
|  [126:3] The LORD  had dealt greatly with us,
|    and we were rejoicing.

|  [126:4] Turn our fortunes, O LORD,
|    as the streams in the Negreb.
|  [126:5] They who sow in tears
|    shall reap with glad shouts.
|  [126:6] Forth they fare, with their burden of seed,
|    and they weep as they go.
|  But home, home, with glad shouts they shall come
|    with their arms full of sheaves.

 [Psalms 127] 

##### Psalm 127 – The Need of Heavenly Help #####

A song of ascents. Of Solomon.

|  [127:1] Unless the LORD  builds the house,
|    those who build it labor in vain.
|  Unless the LORD  guards the city,
|    the watchman wakes in vain.

|  [127:2] In vain you rise early,
|    and finish so late,
|    and so eat sorrow’s bread;
|  for he cares for his loved ones
|    in their sleep.

|  [127:3] Children are a gift of the LORD,
|    the fruit of the womb, a reward.
|  [127:4] Like arrows wielded by warriors,
|    are the children of youth.

|  [127:5] Happy the man who has filled
|    his quiver full of them.
|  He will not be ashamed when he speaks
|    with enemies in the gate.

 [Psalms 128] 

##### Psalm 128 – The Blessings of Home #####

A song of ascents.

|  [128:1] Happy all who fear the LORD,
|    who walk in his ways.
|  [128:2] You will eat what your hands have toiled for,
|    and be happy and prosperous!

|  [128:3] Like a fruitful vine shall your wife be
|    in the innermost room of your house:
|  your children, like olive shoots,
|    round about your table.

|  [128:4] See! This is the blessing
|    of the man who fears the LORD .
|  [128:5] The LORD  shall bless you from Zion.
|    You will see Jerusalem nourish
|  all the days of your life.
|    [128:6] You will see your children’s children.

|      Peace upon Israel.

 [Psalms 129] 

##### Psalm 129 – A Prayer for the Discomfiture of the Enemies of Zion #####

A song of ascents.

|  [129:1] “Sore have they vexed me from youth”
|    thus let Israel say
|  [129:2] “Sore have they vexed me from youth,
|    but they have not prevailed against me.

|  [129:3] “The ploughers ploughed on my back,
|    they made their furrows long.
|  [129:4] But the LORD, who is righteous, has cut
|    the cords of the wicked.”

|  [129:5] Let all who are haters of Zion
|    be put to shame and defeated.
|  [129:6] May they be as the grass on the house-top,
|    which withers before it shoots up;

|  [129:7] which fills not the arms of the reaper,
|    nor the lap of the binder of sheaves
|  [129:8] whereof no one says as they pass,
|    “The blessing of God be upon you.”

|      In the name of the LORD  we bless you.

 [Psalms 130] 

##### Psalm 130 – Out of the Depths #####

A song of ascents.

|  [130:1] Out of the depths
|    I call to you, LORD .
|  [130:2] LORD, hear my voice:
|    give heed with your ears
|    to my loud plea.

|  [130:3] If you should mark sin, LORD,
|    O LORD, who could stand?
|  [130:4] But with you is forgiveness,
|    that you may be feared.

|  [130:5] I wait for the LORD,
|    I wait for his word,
|  [130:6] I look for the LORD
|     more than watchman for morning,
|    than watchman for morning.

|  [130:7] Israel, hope in the LORD :
|    with the LORD  there is love
|  with him plenteous redemption.
|  [130:8] And he redeems Israel
|    from all his iniquities.

 [Psalms 131] 

##### Psalm 131 – As a Little Child #####

A song of ascents. Of David.

|  [131:1] O LORD, my heart is not haughty,
|    my eyes are not lofty,
|  I walk not among great things,
|    things too wonderful for me.

|  [131:2] Yes, I have soothed and stilled myself,
|    like a young child on his mother’s lap;
|    like a young child am I.

|  [131:3] O Israel, hope in the LORD
|     from now and for evermore.

 [Psalms 132] 

##### Psalm 132 – The Ancient Promise to David and Zion #####

|  [132:1] Remember, O LORD, David
|    all his sufferings,
|  [132:2] the oath that he swore to the LORD,
|    and his vow to the Strong One of Jacob,
|  [132:3] never to enter his tent,
|    never to lie on his bed,
|  [132:4] never to give his eyes sleep
|    or his eyelids slumber,
|  [132:5] till he had found a place for the LORD,
|    for the Strong One of Jacob to live in.

|  [132:6] We heard of it in Ephrathah,
|    in the fields of Jaar we found it.
|  [132:7] We went to the place where he dwelt,
|    we bowed ourselves low at his footstool.
|  [132:8] “Arise, LORD, and enter your resting-place,
|    you and your mighty ark.
|  [132:9] Let your priests wear a garment of righteousness,
|    your faithful shout aloud for joy.
|  [132:10] For the sake of David your servant,
|    do not reject your Anointed.”

|  [132:11] The LORD  swore an oath to David
|    an oath that he will not break;
|  “I will set on your throne
|    a prince of your line.
|  [132:12] If your sons keep my covenant
|    and the statutes I teach them,

###### Against Suretyship ######

|  [6:1] My son if you have gone bail for your neighbour,
|    and given your pledge for another;
|  [6:2] if by your own lips you are snared,
|    and are trapped by the words of your mouth:
|  [6:3] then this do, my son, and free yourself,
|    since you have come into his power.
|  Go, stir youself, besiege your neighbour;
|  [6:4] give no sleep to your eyes.
|    nor slumber to your eyelids,
|  [6:5] shake yourself free, like a roe, from the snare,
|    or a bird from the hand of the fowler.

###### Against Indolence ######

|  [6:6] Go to the ant, you sluggard;
|    consider her ways, and be wise,
|  [6:7] without officer, ruler, or chief,
|  [6:8] she provides her bread in the summer.
|    and gathers her food in the harvest.

|  [6:9] How long will you lie, O sluggard?
|    When will you rise from your sleep?
|  [6:10] “Just a little more sleep, a little more slumber,
|    a little more lying with folded hands.”
|  [6:11] So will poverty come on you like a robber,
|    and want like an armed man.

###### Against Underhand Mischief-making ######

|  [6:12] Sunk in wickedness is the man
|    whose speech is ingrained with falsehood –
|  [6:13] who winks his eyes,
|    or shuffles his feet,
|    or makes signs with his fingers,
|  [6:14] gives his mind to the planning of mischief,
|    and always is scattering discord.
|  [6:15] For these things will sudden disaster assail him;
|    he will swiftly be crushed beyond all hope of healing.

###### Seven Detestable Things ######

|  [6:16] Six things there are which the Lord detests,
|    yes, seven does He abhor:
|  [6:17] haughty eyes, a lying tongue,
|    and hands that shed innocent blood,
|  [6:18] a mind that plans wicked devices,
|    and feet that are swift to do wrong,
|  [6:19] a false witness that utters lies,
|    One that scatters strife among brethren.

 [Proverbs 10] 

##### First Collection of Proverbs #####

[10:1] The Proverbs of Solomon:

|  A wise son makes his father glad,
|    but a foolish son is a grief to his mother.
|  [10:2] Treasures wrongly acquired profit nothing,
|    but righteousness saves from death.
|  [10:3] The Lord will not suffer the righteous to hunger,
|    but He will frustrate the desire of the wicked.
|  [10:4] A slack hand creates poverty,
|    but a diligent hand makes rich.
|  [10:5] He that gathers in summer acts wisely;
|    he that sleeps in harvest acts shamefully.
|  [10:6] The blessing of God is on the head of the righteous,
|    but sorrow will cover the face of the wicked.
|  [10:7] The memory of the righteous is blessed,
|    but the name of the wicked will rot.
|  [10:8] A wise man gives heed to commands,
|    but a foolish talker will fall.
|  [10:9] He whose life is blameless walks safely,
|    but he who lives crookedly smarts for it.
|  [10:10] He who winks the eye makes trouble,
|    but frank reproof makes peace.
|  [10:11] A fountain of life is the mouth of the righteous,
|    but the mouth of the wicked is wrapped in violence.
|  [10:12] Hatred stirs up strife,
|    but love hides all transgressions.
|  [10:13] On the lips of a prudent man wisdom is found,
|    but a man without sense needs a rod for his back.
|  [10:14] Wise men keep what they know to themselves,
|    but the mouth of the fool is impending destruction.
|  [10:15] The rich man’s wealth is his fortified city;
|    but the poor, by their poverty, come to destruction.
|  [10:16] The wage of the righteous conduces to life,
|    but their revenue brings the wicked to ruin.
|  [10:17] The way to life is to heed instruction,
|    but to turn from reproof is to go astray.
|  [10:18] Righteous lips cover up hatred,
|    but the slanderer is a fool.
|  [10:19] Where words are many, offences are certain;
|    But he who controls his tongue does wisely.
|  [10:20] The tongue of the just is like choicest silver,
|    but the mind of the wicked is little worth.
|  [10:21] The speech of the righteous is sustenance to many,
|    but lack of sense is the death of fools.
|  [10:22] It is only the blessing of God that brings wealth,
|    and He adds no sorrow therewith.
|  [10:23] To a fool the doing of wrong is as sport,
|    but a man of sense abhors it.
|  [10:24] What the wicked feared will befall him,
|    but the desire of the righteous will be granted.
|  [10:25] When the whirlwind passes, the wicked will vanish,
|    but the righteous is firmly established forever.
|  [10:26] As vinegar to the teeth, and as smoke to the eyes,
|    even so is the sluggard to them that send him.
|  [10:27] The fear of the Lord prolongs life,
|    but the years of the wicked are shortened.
|  [10:28] The hope of the righteous will end in gladness,
|    but the wicked will fail of their expectation.
|  [10:29] To the man that is blameless the Lord is a strong-hold,
|    but terror and ruin to those that do evil.
|  [10:30] The righteous will be unmoved forever,
|    but the wicked will have no home in the land.
|  [10:31] The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom,
|    but the man of false tongue will be rooted out.
|  [10:32] The lips of the righteous utter good-will;
|    but the mouth of the wicked, malice.

 [Proverbs 11] 

|  [11:1] The Lord detests a false balance,
|    but a just weight is his delight.
|  [11:2] Pride is sure to be followed by shame,
|    but modesty is wisdom.
|  [11:3] Their integrity guides the upright,
|    but the false are destroyed by their crookedness.
|  [11:4] In the day of wrath riches are useless,
|    but righteousness saves from death.
|  [11:5] The path of the blameless is smoothed by his righteousness,
|    but the wicked will fall by his wickedness.
|  [11:6] The upright are saved by their righteousness,
|    but the false are caught in their evil desires.
|  [11:7] When a wicked man dies, his hope perishes –
|    the hope of the godless perishes.
|  [11:8] The righteous is rescued from trouble,
|    and the wicked takes his place.
|  [11:9] By slander the godless would ruin his neighbour,
|    but the righteous are rescued by knowledge.
|  [11:10] When the righteous flourish, the city rejoices;
|    when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.
|  [11:11] By the blessing of the upright, the city is exalted;
|    by the mouth of the wicked it is overthrown.
|  [11:12] A man has no sense that despises his neighbour;
|    a man of prudence holds his tongue.
|  [11:13] Who carries tales divulges secrets,
|    but a trustworthy man conceals a matter.
|  [11:14] Where guidance is lacking, a people must fall;
|    but that people is safe that is rich in counsellors.
|  [11:15] He who goes bail for another will suffer,
|    but he who abhors being surety is sure.
|  [11:16] A gracious woman obtains honour,
|    but a throne of dishonour is she who hates justice.
|    Indolent men never come to wealth,
|    but riches are won by the men that are diligent.
|  [11:17] The kind man does good to himself;
|    the cruel man injures himself.
|  [11:18] The gain of the wicked is but an illusion,
|    but he who sows righteousness wins the true wages.
|  [11:19] Devotion to righteousness leads to life;
|    the pursuit of wickedness ends in death.
|  [11:20] The Lord abhors the mind that is crooked,
|    but those who walk blamelessly are his delight.
|  [11:21] Most surely the wicked will not go unpunished,
|    but the righteous folk will escape.
|  [11:22] Like a golden ring in the snout of a swine
|    is a beautiful woman without discretion.
|  [11:23] The desire of the righteous will issue in good,
|    but the hope of the wicked in wrath.
|  [11:24] One man is generous, yet grows ever richer;
|    another is mean, yet he only grows poorer.
|  [11:25] The liberal soul will be enriched;
|    and he who waters, himself will be watered.
|  [11:26] He who holds up corn will be cursed by the people,
|    but blessings will be on his head that sells it.
|  [11:27] He who aims at the thing that is good will win favour,
|    but ruin will come upon him who seeks evil.
|  [11:28] He who trusts in his riches will wither,
|    but like green leaves the righteous will flourish.
|  [11:29] He that harms his household will reap the wind,
|    and the fool will be slave to the man of wisdom.
|  [11:30] Life is the fruit of righteousness,
|    but rapine destroys men’s lives.
|  [11:31] If the righteous are punished on earth,
|    how much more the sinful and wicked!

 [Proverbs 12] 

|  [12:1] He who loves knowledge loves discipline,
|    but he that hates reproof is a boor.
|  [12:2] A good man wins the Lord’s good-will,
|    but a man of evil designs He condemns.
|  [12:3] By wickedness no man can stand forever,
|    but the root of the righteous remains unmoved.
|  [12:4] A worthy wife is a crown to her husband,
|    but one that brings shame is as rot in his bones.
|  [12:5] The aims of the righteous are just;
|    the designs of the wicked are treacherous.
|  [12:6] The words of the wicked lurk for blood,
|    but the speech of the upright delivers.
|  [12:7] The wicked will be overthrown and vanish,
|    but the house of the righteous will stand.
|  [12:8] A man is commended according to his insight.
|    but a wrong-headed man is despised.
|  [12:9] Better a man of no rank, with a servant,
|    than one who apes greatness and yet has no bread.
|  [12:10] A righteous man cares for the life of his beast,
|    but the heart of the wicked is cruel.
|  [12:11] He who tills his land will have plenty of bread.
|    but he who pursues empty aims will have none.
|  [12:12] The wicked is snared by his wickedness,
|    but the root of the righteous endures.
|  [12:13] By the sin of his lips is the wicked ensnared,
|    but the righteous escapes from trouble.
|  [12:14] The words of a man bring forth good fruit in plenty,
|    and the deeds of his hands will come back upon him.
|  [12:15] A fool is certain his way is right,
|    but a wise man listens to counsel.
|  [12:16] A fool displays his anger at once,
|    but a prudent man hides an affront.
|  [12:17] One who speaks out the truth affirms justice.
|    but a false witness utters lies.
|  [12:18] The chatter of some is like sword-thrusts.
|    but the tongue of the wise is healing.
|  [12:19] The man who speaks truth stands forever,
|    but the false tongue is but for a moment.
|  [12:20] Hearts of deceit have the men who plan evil,
|    but happy are those who plan other men’s good.
|  [12:21] No evil thing can befall the righteous,
|    but the wicked are full of misfortune.
|  [12:22] The Lord abhors lying lips,
|    But delighteth in those that deal faithfully.
|  [12:23] A man of prudence conceals what he knows,
|    but a fool shouts his folly aloud.
|  [12:24] The diligent comes to power,
|    but the slothful becomes a serf.
|  [12:25] Care bows down a man’s heart,
|    but a good word makes it glad.
|  [12:26] The righteous departs from evil;
|    but the way of the wicked is error.
|  [12:27] The indolent man will not hunt his game,
|    but the diligent man wins precious wealth.
|  [12:28] In the path of righteousness there is life,
|    but the way of wickedness leads to death.

 [Proverbs 13] 

|  [13:1] A wise son loves instruction,
|    but a scorner listens not to rebuke.
|  [13:2] A good man enjoys the fruits of his speech,
|    but the false are greedy for rapine.
|  [13:3] He that guards his mouth preserves his life,
|    but a wide open mouth brings a man to ruin.
|  [13:4] The sluggard desires and has not.
|    but the diligent is enriched.
|  [13:5] A righteous man hates deception,
|    but the wicked act basely and shamefully.
|  [13:6] Righteousness guards the man of integrity,
|    but sin overturns the wicked.
|  [13:7] Some pretend to be rich, and have nothing at all;
|    some pretend to be poor, and are rolling in wealth.
|  [13:8] A man’s riches may ransom his life.
|    but a poor man listens not to rebuke.
|  [13:9] The light of the righteous shines on,
|    but the lamp of the wicked goes out.
|  [13:10] Pride causes nothing but strife.
|    but with those that take counsel is wisdom.
|  [13:11] Wealth gathered in haste will diminish,
|    but amassed by degrees it will grow.
|  [13:12] Hope deferred makes sick the heart,
|    but a wish fullilled is life.
|  [13:13] He who scorns the word will perish,
|    but who fears the commandment is safe.
|  [13:14] The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life,
|    whereby to avoid the snares of death.
|  [13:15] Fine intelligence wins favour,
|    but the way of the false is their ruin.
|  [13:16] The prudent act always with insight,
|    but the fool flaunts his folly.
|  [13:17] An incompetent messenger ruins an enterprise,
|    but a trustworthy envoy is healing.
|  [13:18] To reject instruction spells shame and poverty,
|    but to heed admonition leads to honour.
|  [13:19] Sweet is desire fulfilled,
|    but fools hate to turn from evil.
|  [13:20] He that walks with the wise will be wise,
|    but the comrade of fools will smart for it.
|  [13:21] Sinners are chased by misfortune,
|    but good overtakes the righteous.
|  [13:22] The good man leaves wealth to his children’s children,
|    but the wealth of the sinner is stored for the righteous.
|  [13:23] The ground of the poor yields food in abundance,
|    but some by injustice are swept away.
|  [13:24] He that spares his rod hates his son,
|    but he that loves him chastises him.
|  [13:25] The righteous, when hungry, may eat their fill.
|    but the wicked are empty within.

 [Proverbs 14] 

|  [14:1] A wise woman builds her house,
|    but a fool tears it down with her hands.
|  [14:2] The man who fears God lives honestly,
|    but the man that is crooked despises Him.
|  [14:3] The speech of a fool is a rod for his back,
|    but the words of the wise preserve them
|  [14:4] Where no oxen are, there can be no corn;
|    but plenty of oxen means plenty of produce.
|  [14:5] A trustworthy witness does not lie.
|    but a false witness utters lies.
|  [14:6] A scorner seeks wisdom in vain,
|    but to prudent men knowledge is easy.
|  [14:7] Get you out of a foolish man’s presence,
|    for his lips do not utter knowledge.
|  [14:8] The shrewd show their wisdom by watching their way,
|    but the folly of foolish men leads them astray.
|  [14:9] Guilt has its home among fools,
|    but God’s favour abides with the upright.
|  [14:10] The heart knows its own bitterness,
|    and no stranger can share in its joy.
|  [14:11] The house of the wicked will be destroyed,
|    but the tent of the upright will flourish.
|  [14:12] Many a way seems straight to a man
|    which leads at the last to death.
|  [14:13] Even in laughter the heart may be sad,
|    and the end of joy may be sorrow.
|  [14:14] He who swerves from the right will pay dearly for his conduct,
|    but the good man will reap the fruit of his deeds.
|  [14:15] The simple believe every word,
|    but the shrewd look well to their steps.
|  [14:16] A wise man anxiously shrinks from evil,
|    but a fool plunges into it jauntily.
|  [14:17] A man of quick temper acts foolishly,
|    but a prudent man is patient.
|  [14:18] The simple come into possession of folly,
|    But the wise win the crown of knowledge.
|  [14:19] The evil must bow before the good,
|    and the wicked crouch down at the gates of the righteous.
|  [14:20] The poor man is hated even by his neighbour,
|    but the rich has many friends.
|  [14:21] He that despises his neighbour sins,
|    but happy is he that does pity the poor.
|  [14:22] Surely those that plan evil will stray to destruction,
|    but those that plan good meet with kindness and faithfulness.
|  [14:23] In all labour there is profit,
|    but mere talk tends only to penury.
|  [14:24] The crown of the wise is their wisdom,
|    and the garland of fools is their folly.
|  [14:25] A truthful witness saves life.
|    but one who speaks falsely destroys it.
|  [14:26] He that fears the Lord has strong ground of confidence.
|    To the children of such he is refuge.
|  [14:27] The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life,
|    whereby to avoid the snares of death.
|  [14:28] Glory falls to the monarch whose people are many,
|    but a prince comes to ruin whose people are few.
|  [14:29] The man of patience shows much good sense,
|    but the quick-tempered man shows great folly.
|  [14:30] A tranquil mind is the life of the body,
|    but passion rots the bones.
|  [14:31] He that crushes the needy reviles his maker,
|    but he that is kind to the poor does him honour.
|  [14:32] The wicked is overthrown by his wickedness.
|    but the righteous has a refuge in his integrity,
|  [14:33] wisdom dwells in the heart of the prudent,
|    but folly in the heart of fools.
|  [14:34] Righteousness exalts a nation,
|    but sin is a people’s disgrace.
|  [14:35] A competent servant enjoys the king’s favour,
|    but scandalous service incurs his wrath.

 [Proverbs 15] 

|  [15:1] A soft answer turns away wrath,
|    but provocative speech stirs up anger.
|  [15:2] The tongue of the wise drops knowledge,
|    but the mouth of fools pours out folly.
|  [15:3] The eyes of the Lord are everywhere,
|    watching the bad and the good.
|  [15:4] A soothing tongue is life,
|    but violent words break the spirit.
|  [15:5] A fool despises his father’s instruction.
|    but he that regards reproof shows wisdom.
|  [15:6] In the house of the righteous is abundance of wealth,
|    but the revenue of the wicked is cut off.
|  [15:7] The lips of the wise disperse knowledge,
|    but the mind of fools is unstable.
|  [15:8] The Lord abhors the sacrifice of the wicked,
|    but the prayer of the upright he welcomes.
|  [15:9] The Lord abhors the way of the wicked,
|    but he loves the man that is bent upon righteousness.
|  [15:10] He that leaves the way will have discipline sore,
|    he that hates reproof will die.
|  [15:11] Before the Lord Sheol and Abaddon lie open;
|    how much more the hearts of men!
|  [15:12] A scoffer loves not reproof,
|    he refuses to go with the wise.
|  [15:13] Joyous heart makes happy face,
|    but a sorrowful heart makes a stricken spirit
|  [15:14] The mind of the wise seeks knowledge,
|    but the mouth of fools feeds on folly.
|  [15:15] To the sad every day is a bad day,
|    but an endless feast to the cheerful.
|  [15:16] Better is little, with the fear of the Lord,
|    than abundance of treasure and trouble therewith.
|  [15:17] Better a dish of herbs, with love,
|    than a fatted ox, with hatred.
|  [15:18] An angry man stirs up strife,
|    but a patient man stills contention.
|  [15:19] The way of the sluggard is hedged with thorns,
|    but the path of the diligent runs like a highway.
|  [15:20] A wise son makes his father glad,
|    but a fool of a man despises his mother.
|  [15:21] Folly is joy to a man without sense,
|    but a man of good sense is straightforward.
|  [15:22] Plans are frustrated where there is no counsel;
|    but, when many advise, they succeed.
|  [15:23] Joy comes to the man who makes happy retort;
|    and a word in season, how good it is!
|  [15:24] The wise man’s path goes upward to life;
|    He avoids the way to Sheol beneath.
|  [15:25] The Lord uproots the house of the proud,
|    But the bounds of the widow he firmly maintains.
|  [15:26] Evil devices the Lord abhors,
|    but gracious words are his delight.
|  [15:27] He that is grasping destroys his own house,
|    but he who hates presents will live.
|  [15:28] Faithfulness broods in the heart of the righteous,
|    but evil pours from the mouth of the wicked.
|  [15:29] The Lord is far from the wicked,
|    but the prayer of the righteous he hears.
|  [15:30] Shining eyes gladden the heart,
|    and good news fattens the bones.
|  [15:31] He that listens to wholesome reproof
|    will dwell among the wise.
|  [15:32] He despises himself who rejecteth instruction.
|    but he gains understanding who heeds reproof.
|  [15:33] The fear of the Lord is instruction in wisdom,
|    and honour comes after humility.

 [Proverbs 16] 

|  [16:1] Man may order his thoughts,
|    but the word on his tongue is from God.
|  [16:2] A man’s life may seem thoroughly pure to himself,
|    but the Lord weighs the spirit.
|  [16:3] Commit your work to the Lord,
|    and so will your plans succeed.
|  [16:4] God created each thing for an end of its own,
|    even the wicked for the day of disaster.
|  [16:5] All the proud-minded the Lord abhors;
|    assuredly none will escape unpunished.
|  [16:6] By kindness and faithfulness sin is atoned for,
|    and through fear of the Lord men escape disaster.
|  [16:7] When the Lord is pleased with the ways of a man,
|    he makes even his foes to become his friends.
|  [16:8] Better a little, with righteousness.
|    than great revenues with injustice.
|  [16:9] Man plans out his way,
|    but the Lord directs his steps.

|  [16:10] The lips of the king are an oracle,
|    and the sentence he utters infallible.
|  [16:11] Balance and scales are the Lord’s,
|    all the weights of the bag are his work.
|  [16:12] Kings shrink with abhorrence from wrong-doing,
|    for a throne is established by righteousness.
|  [16:13] Honest lips are a king’s delight;
|    he loves the man that speaks truly.
|  [16:14] The wrath of a king bodes death,
|    but a wise man knows how to appease it.
|  [16:15] When the king’s face shines, there is life:
|    like a cloud of spring-rain is his favour.

|  [16:16] Wisdom is better to win than gold,
|    and understanding is choicer than silver.
|  [16:17] The path of the upright avoids misfortune;
|    he guards his life who gives heed to his way.
|  [16:18] Pride goes before destruction.
|    and a haughty spirit before a fall.
|  [16:19] Better be lowly of mind with the poor
|    than divide the spoil with the great.
|  [16:20] He that gives heed to the word will be prosperous;
|    happy the man who trusts the Lord.
|  [16:21] Wise men are called men of insight,
|    and winsome speech adds to persuasiveness.
|  [16:22] To a wise man is wisdom a fountain of life,
|    but fools are chastised by their folly.
|  [16:23] A wise mind utters thoughtful speech.
|    and touches the lips to persuasiveness.
|  [16:24] Winsome words are a honeycomb,
|    sweet to the soul and healing to the body.
|  [16:25] Many a way seems straight to a man
|    Which leads at the last to death.
|  [16:26] The labourer’s appetite labours for him,
|    for his hungry mouth urges him on.
|  [16:27] A depraved man digs a pit of mischief,
|    while his lips are touched as with scorching fire.
|  [16:28] A false man scatters discord,
|    and a whisperer separates friends.
|  [16:29] A man of violence entices his neighbour,
|    and leads him into a hurtful way.
|  [16:30] He who closes his eyes is devising some lie;
|    He who tightens his lips has concocted some mischief.
|  [16:31] The grey head is a crown of glory,
|    which is won by a righteous life.
|  [16:32] Patience is better than warrior’s strength,
|    and to rule o’er oneself than to capture a city.
|  [16:33] The lot is cast into the lap,
|    but the issue lies wholly with God.

 [Proverbs 17] 

|  [17:1] Better a bit of dry bread, with peace,
|    than a house full of feasting and strife.
|  [17:2] A wise slave becomes lord of a profligate son;
|    he will share the estate with the brothers.
|  [17:3] Like the smelter for silver, the furnace for gold,
|    is the Lord who tests the heart.
|  [17:4] A bad man gives heed to wicked words;
|    a false man listens to mischievous speech.
|  [17:5] He that mocks the poor reviles his maker;
|    he that joys at misfortune will not go unpunished.
|  [17:6] The crown of old men is children’s children,
|    and the glory of children is their father.
|  [17:7] On the lips of a fool honest words are unseemly;
|    much more lying words on the lips of a noble man.
|  [17:8] A bribe is like a magic stone;
|    he that offers it prospers wherever he turns.
|  [17:9] He that covers up wrong seeks love,
|    but the gossip estranges his friend.
|  [17:10] A rebuke cuts a wise man more deeply
|    than a hundred stripes cut a fool.
|  [17:11] The bad man is bent on playing the rebel;
|    so a pitiless angel is sent against him.
|  [17:12] Meet a bear robbed of her whelps
|    rather than a fool in his folly.
|  [17:13] Misfortune will haunt the house
|    of the man who for good returns evil.
|  [17:14] Strife may be started by idle words;
|    so give over contention before there is quarrelling.
|  [17:15] To acquit the guilty and condemn the innocent
|    are both alike to the Lord detestable.
|  [17:16] Why does the fool bring a fee
|    to buy wisdom, when he has no mind?
|  [17:17] A true friend loves at all times;
|    a brother is born for adversity.
|  [17:18] He that gives his hand is a fool –
|    the man who goes bail for another.
|  [17:19] He loves wounds who loves strife,
|    and the man who builds loftily seeks destruction.
|  [17:20] The false heart finds no good.
|    and the wily tongue comes to disaster.
|  [17:21] A man begets a fool to his sorrow;
|    no joy can there be for the father of a fool.
|  [17:22] A happy heart is a healthful medicine,
|    but a broken spirit dries up the bones.
|  [17:23] The wicked accept a bribe
|    to deflect the course of justice.
|  [17:24] The man of good sense has his gaze fixed on wisdom,
|    but a fool has his eyes at the end of the earth.
|  [17:25] A foolish son is a grief to his father,
|    and bitterness to her that bore him.
|  [17:26] Since it is not right even to fine the innocent,
|    to scourge men of honour is utterly wrong.
|  [17:27] He that spares his words is truly wise,
|    and a cool-tempered man is a man of discretion.
|  [17:28] Even a fool may, if silent, be taken for wise –
|    for a man of good sense, if he keeps his lips closed.

 [Proverbs 18] 

|  [18:1] The estranged friend seeks an occasion of quarrel;
|    he tries by all means to stir up strife.
|  [18:2] A fool has no pleasure in prudence,
|    but only in self-display.
|  [18:3] Wrongdoing brings down contempt,
|    and disgrace follows dishonour.
|  [18:4] The words that are found on wise lips are deep waters,
|    a bubbling brook, a fountain of life.
|  [18:5] It is wrong to favour the guilty,
|    to give verdict against the innocent.
|  [18:6] A fool by his talk is involved in disputes,
|    and his words cry aloud for a beating.
|  [18:7] The mouth of a fool is his ruin;
|    his lips are a trap to him.
|  [18:8] Slanderous words are like dainty morsels;
|    down they ghde to the innermost being.
|  [18:9] He that is slack in his business
|    is brother to him that destroys.
|  [18:10] The Lord is a mighty tower;
|    the righteous run in and are safe.
|  [18:11] A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city,
|    and like a high wall are his riches.
|  [18:12] Pride of heart goes before destruction,
|    and before honour goes humility.
|  [18:13] For a man to answer before he has heard
|    is folly and shame to him.
|  [18:14] A man’s spirit sustains his weakness,
|    but who can bear a crushed spirit?
|  [18:15] A sensible mind acquires knowledge,
|    and a wise ear seeks out wisdom.
|  [18:16] Presents prepare a man’s way,
|    and bring him before the great.
|  [18:17] The first man to plead seems right,
|    but then comes the other and tests him.
|  [18:18] The lot puts an end to disputes,
|    and decides between the mighty.
|  [18:19] The rich man’s wealth is his fortified city;
|    his riches resemble the bars of a fortress.
|  [18:20] A man’s words will bear for him plenty of fruit.
|    and his speech will have an abundant harvest.
|  [18:21] Death and life are in the power of the tongue,
|    and those who love it must eat its fruit.
|  [18:22] He that finds a wife has found a blessing,
|    and won a sign of the Lord’s good will.
|  [18:23] A poor man speaks like a supplicant,
|    but the rich man answers gruffly.
|  [18:24] There are friends that seek nothing but company,
|    and a friend who clings closer than brother.

 [Proverbs 19] 

|  [19:1] Better a poor man whose life is blameless
|    than one who is crooked, although he be rich.
|  [19:2] To act without knowledge is foolish;
|    the hasty foot misses the goal.
|  [19:3] A man ruins his life by his folly,
|    And then he fumes against God.
|  [19:4] Wealth adds many friends,
|    but the friend of the poor man withdraws.
|  [19:5] A false witness will not go unpunished;
|    he that utters lies will not escape.
|  [19:6] To the liberal many pay court;
|    all are friends of the man who gives.
|  [19:7] A poor man’s brothers all hate him;
|    much more do his friends stand aloof.
|  [19:8] He loves his life who acquires wisdom,
|    and he finds good who observes understanding.
|  [19:9] A false witness will not go unpunished;
|    he that utters lies will perish.
|  [19:10] A luxurious life for a fool is unseemly;
|    much more for a servant to rule over princes.
|  [19:11] By forbearance a man shows his wisdom;
|    to ignore an offence is his glory.
|  [19:12] The wrath of a king is like the growl of a lion,
|    his favour like dew on the grass.
|  [19:13] A silly son is his father’s ruin,
|    and a quarrelsome wife is an endless drip.
|  [19:14] House and wealth come to men from their fathers,
|    but a prudent wife is the gift of the Lord.
|  [19:15] Indolence ends in a deep heavy sleep,
|    and the man that is slack will be hungry.
|  [19:16] He that keeps the commandment preserves his life;
|    he that spurns the word will die.
|  [19:17] To be kind to the poor is to lend to the Lord,
|    who will pay the good deed back.
|  [19:18] Chastise your son, while yet there is hope,
|    and set not your heart on having him ruined.
|  [19:19] He who pays a fine is very angry.
|    but, if he should scoff, he must pay still more.
|  [19:20] Listen to counsel, receive instruction,
|    so that you may be wise in the days to come.
|  [19:21] A man has many a plan in his mind;
|    but the Lord has his purpose – and that will stand.
|  [19:22] A man’s kindness brings him return;
|    better be poor than a cheat.
|  [19:23] The fear of the Lord is the pathway to life,
|    to that quiet content which no evil can visit.
|  [19:24] The lazy man buries his hand in the dish,
|    and refuses to carry it back to his mouth.
|  [19:25] When a scoffer is beaten, a simpleton learns,
|    but reproof is enough to teach sensible men.
|  [19:26] That son is a thorough disgrace and scoundrel
|    who maltreats his father and drives out his mother.
|  [19:27] Cease, my son, to despise instruction,
|    to wander away from the words of knowledge.
|  [19:28] An unprincipled witness scoffs at justice,
|    and the mouth of the wicked pours out wrong.
|  [19:29] The scourgeo is prepared for the scoffer.
|    and stripes for the back of the fool.

 [Proverbs 20] 

|  [20:1] Wine is a mocker, strong drink is a brawler,
|    and they who reel under it do not act wisely.
|  [20:2] The wrath of a king is like the growl of a lion,
|    and he who provokes him endangers his life.
|  [20:3] It honours a man to keep from strife,
|    but every fool shows his teeth.
|  [20:4] In autumn the lazy man will not plough;
|    so in harvest he asks for a crop in vain.
|  [20:5] A plan may lie deep in the heart like well-water,
|    but a skilful man knows how to draw it up.
|  [20:6] Many a man professes kindness,
|    but who can find a man of fidelity?
|  [20:7] Happy the sons that come after the man
|    whose life has been righteous and blameless.
|  [20:8] Throned on the seat of judgment,
|    the king sifts all wrong with his eyes.
|  [20:9] Who can say, “I have cleansed my heart,
|    pure and sinless am I”?
|  [20:10] Divers weights and divers measures
|    are both alike to the Lord detestable.
|  [20:11] Even a child is known by his deeds,
|    as his conduct is good or bad.
|  [20:12] The hearing ear and the seeing eye
|    are both alike the Lord’s creation.
|  [20:13] Love not sleep, lest you come to poverty;
|    open your eyes, that your bread may be plentiful.
|  [20:14] “Bad, bad,” says the buyer;
|    but when he is gone, he brags.
|  [20:15] Lips of wisdom are store of gold,
|    wealth of coral and precious vessels.
|  [20:16] Take the garment of him who goes bail for another,
|    and hold it in pledge for that other.
|  [20:17] Bread won by deception tastes sweet to a man,
|    but at last his mouth will be hiled with gravel.
|  [20:18] Take advice in arranging your plans,
|    and do not make war without guidance.
|  [20:19] Who carries tales divulges secrets;
|    have nothing to do with a gossip.
|  [20:20] He who curses his father or mother –
|    his lamp will go out in thick darkness.
|  [20:21] Wealth hastily gotten at first
|    will remain unblessed in the end.
|  [20:22] Do not say, “I will pay back evil”;
|    but wait for the help of the Lord.
|  [20:23] Divers weights the Lord abhors;
|    false balances are not good.
|  [20:24] Since the Lord controls a man’s steps,
|    how can man understand his way?
|  [20:25] A man is ensnared if he dedicates rashly,
|    and only makes inquiry after his vow.
|  [20:26] A wise king winnows the wicked,
|    and passes the wheel over them,
|  [20:27] The spirit of man is the lamp of the Lord,
|    searching every room of his being.
|  [20:28] Kindness and faithfulness guard the king,
|    and his throne is established by justice.
|  [20:29] The glory of youth is its strength,
|    but grey hair is the beauty of age.
|  [20:30] A bad man is doomed to the lash, whose stripes
|    will cut to his inmost soul.

 [Proverbs 21] 

|  [21:1] The Lord guides the king’s heart like watercourses,
|    turning it whither He will.
|  [21:2] A man’s life may seem thoroughly straight to himself,
|    but the Lord weighs the heart.
|  [21:3] The doing of justice and right
|    to the Lord is more welcome than sacrifice.
|  [21:4] A haughty look, a heart of pride,
|    the soil of the wicked is sin.
|  [21:5] The plans of the diligent issue in gain,
|    but too much haste leads only to want.
|  [21:6] He that wins him wealth by a fraudulent tongue
|    is pursuing a breath and a deadly snare.
|  [21:7] The violence of the wicked will sweep them away,
|    because they refuse to act justly.
|  [21:8] The way of the vicious is crooked,
|    but a pure man does what is straight.
|  [21:9] It is better to live on the roof in a corner,
|    than in a spacious house with a quarrelsome woman.
|  [21:10] The wicked man’s passion is all to do harm;
|    he looks on his neighbour with pitiless eye.
|  [21:11] When a scoffer is punished, a fool becomes wise;
|    but the wise are receptive, and learn by instruction.
|  [21:12] The Lord considers the righteous,
|    but the house of the wicked he overthrows.
|  [21:13] He that stops his ears at the cry of the poor
|    will find his own call unanswered.
|  [21:14] A gift in secret extinguishes anger,
|    and a bribe in the bosom soothes strong indignation.
|  [21:15] When justice is done, the righteous rejoice;
|    but evil-doers are ruined.
|  [21:16] The man who strays from wisdom’s way
|    will rest where the dead are gathered.
|  [21:17] The lover of pleasure will come to want,
|    and lovers of wine and oil cannot grow rich.
|  [21:18] For the righteous the wicked is ransom;
|    the false take the place of the upright.
|  [21:19] It is better to live in a desert land
|    than with a provoking and quarrelsome woman.
|  [21:20] In the wise man’s homestead is precious treasure,
|    but a silly man swallows it up.
|  [21:21] The pursuit of justice and kindness
|    is crowned with life and honour.
|  [21:22] The wise man scales the strong men’s city,
|    and brings down the stronghold in which they trusted.
|  [21:23] He who guards his mouth and his tongue
|    preserves himself from trouble.
|  [21:24] Scoffers men call the proud and haughty
|    who act with insolent pride.
|  [21:25] The desire of the sluggard will slay him,
|    for his hands refuse to work.
|  [21:26] Desires and petitions are endless,
|    but the righteous gives unsparingly.
|  [21:27] The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable;
|    much more when offered with vile intent.
|  [21:28] A lying witness will perish,
|    but a trustworthy witness will stand forever.
|  [21:29] The wicked put on a bold face,
|    but the upright take heed to their conduct.
|  [21:30] No wisdom nor understanding
|    nor counsel can match the Lord.
|  [21:31] For the day of battle the horse may be harnessed,
|    but only the Lord can dispense the victory.

 [Proverbs 22] 

|  [22:1] A fair name is more to be chosen than wealth;
|    men’s regard is far better than silver and gold.
|  [22:2] The rich and the poor meet together;
|    the Lord is the maker of both.
|  [22:3] The prudent scent mischief and hide;
|    the simple go on and are punished.
|  [22:4] The reward of the humble who fear the Lord
|    is riches and honour and life.
|  [22:5] On the way of the crooked lie traps and snares;

|  [22:6] Train up a child for his destined way,
|    and, even when old, he will not depart from it.
|  [22:7] The rich lords it over the poor,
|    and the borrower is slave to the lender.
|  [22:8] He that sows wrong will reap trouble,
|    and the gain he has toiled for will vanish.
|  [22:9] The man with the kindly eye will be blessed,
|    for he gives of his bread to the poor.
|  [22:10] Expel the scoffer and discord will vanish,
|    and strife and insult cease.
|  [22:11] The pure in heart are beloved of the Lord,
|    and the winsome of speech have the king for a friend.
|  [22:12] The Lord is watching, alert and aware,
|    nd the aims of the false he subverts.
|  [22:13] The lazy man says, “There’s a lion outside.
|    on the street I am like to be murdered.”
|  [22:14] The lewd woman’s mouth is a deep, deep pit;
|    he who angers the Lord will fall into it.
|  [22:15] Folly is bound to the mind of a child,
|    but the rod of correction removes it.
|  [22:16] He who crushes the poor in the end but enriches him,
|    but a gift to the rich only tends to his poverty.

 [Proverbs 22] 

##### Second Collection of Proverbs #####

|  [22:17] Incline your ear and hear my words,
|    and set your heart to know their beauty.
|  [22:18] Keep them in your mind,
|    have them ever fixed on your lips.
|  [22:19] That your trust may be in the Lord
|    I teach you them this day,
|  [22:20] As I wrote for you heretofore
|    concerning counsels of wisdom –
|  [22:21] to acquaint you with words of truth,
|    and with answers for those who would question you.

|  [22:22] Rob not the poor because he is poor,
|    and crush not the weak in the gate;
|  [22:23] For the Lord will defend their cause,
|    and will rob of their lives those who rob them.

|  [22:24] Make no friend of a man prone to anger,
|    nor go with a man of passion,
|  [22:25] in case you learn his ways.
|    and get yourself ensnared.

|  [22:26] Be not one of those that give pledges,
|    of those that are surety for debt;
|  [22:27] for if you have nothing to pay,
|    your bed will be taken from under you.

|  [22:28] Remove not the ancient landmark
|    established by your fathers.
|  [22:29] Do you see a man expert in his business?
|    He will stand in the presence of kings.
|    but before obscure men he will not stand.

 [Proverbs 23] 

|  [23:1] If you sit at a ruler’s table,
|    consider well who is before you;
|  [23:2] and set a knife to your throat,
|    if you be a hearty eater.

|  [23:4] Toil not to make yourself rich,
|    desist from this your purpose;
|  [23:5] for no sooner seen than gone.
|    For riches make themselves wings
|    like an eagle that flies towards heaven.

|  [23:6] Do not dine with a niggardly man,
|    and do not fancy his dainties;
|    [23:7] for a reckoning soul has he.
|  He tells you to eat and drink,
|    but his heart is not with yours.
|  [23:8] You must spit out the piece you have eaten,
|    for it is bread of deceit.

|  [23:9] Speak not in the ears of a fool.
|    For your wisest words he despises –
|    your fair discourse is in vain.

|  [23:10] Remove not the widow’s landmark,
|    nor enter the fields of the fatherless;
|  [23:11] for they have a mighty champion,
|    who will plead their cause against you.

|  [23:12] Apply your mind to instruction,
|    your ear to the words of knowledge.
|  [23:13] Leave not a child unchastised,
|    for your beating will save him from death.
|  [23:14] It is for you to beat him.
|    and so will you save him from Sheol.
|  [23:15] My son, if your heart be wise,
|    then my heart too will be glad.
|  [23:16] I will rejoice from my soul,
|    when your lips utter words of rectitude.
|  [23:17] Be not envious of sinners,
|    but ever fear the Lord;
|  [23:18] for there is a future for you.
|    and your hope will not be cut off.

|  [23:19] Listen, my son, and be wise,
|    and walk in the way of prudence.
|  [23:20] Mix not with men that drink wine,
|    or that gorge themselves with flesh;
|  [23:21] for gorging and drink make men paupers,
|    and drowsiness covers with rags.

|  [23:22] Listen to the father that begat you,
|    and despise not your aged mother;
|  [23:25] But let your father be glad,
|    and make your mother happy.
|  [23:24] For a righteous son makes a glad, glad father,
|    and a prudent son is the joy of his mother.

|  [23:26] Give heed to me, my son.
|    Let your eyes take note of my ways.
|  [23:27] For a deep, deep pit is the harlot,
|    the lewd woman a narrow well.
|  [23:28] She lies in wait like a robber,
|    and many are they she plunders.

###### The Peril of Wine ######

|  [23:29] Who is it that cries, “Ah! Woe is me!”
|    Who is it that has quarrels and plaints?
|    Who is it that has senseless bruises?
|    And who has the dull red eyes?
|  [23:30] Those that linger over wine,
|    those that drink spiced wine with a relish.
|  [23:31] Look not on the ruddy wine,
|    when in the cup it sparkles,
|    smoothly it glides down;
|  [23:32] but at last it bites like a serpent,
|    and stings like an adder.
|  [23:33] Strange things your eyes behold,
|    your mind and your speech go a-wandering;
|  [23:34] Like one riding the sea are you
|    in the throes of a violent storm.
|  [23:35] I was struck, but I feel no pain,
|    of the blows I am all unconscious.
|  O when will I wake from my wine?
|    I would seek it once again.

 [Proverbs 24] 

|  [24:1] Be not envious of evil men,
|    and do not desire to be with them;
|  [24:2] for they cherish designs of plunder,
|    and mischief is on their lips.

|  [24:3] By wisdom a house is built up,
|    by intelligence it is established;
|  [24:4] by knowledge its shambers are filled
|    with all precious and pleasant substance.

|  [24:5] Wise men are better than strong men,
|    and knowledge is better than might;
|  [24:6] for wars are waged by wise guidance.
|    and victory lies in counsellors.

|  [24:7] Wisdom is too high for a fool;
|    so he opens not his mouth in the gate.
|  [24:8] The man who deviseth mischief
|    is known among men as a schemer.
|  [24:9] The scheming of fools is sin,
|    and the scoffer is hated of men.

|  [24:10] If you have been slack, in the day of distress
|    your resource will be scanty.
|  [24:11] Rescue those that are taken to death;
|    save those that are tottering to slaughter.
|  [24:12] If you say, “It is not in my power,”
|    he who weighs the heart, he discerns;
|  He who watches your soul, he knows,
|    and on each he will bring back his deeds.

|  [24:13] As the honey you eat, my son, is wholesome.
|    and sweet to your taste is the honeycomb,
|    [24:14] even so, be assured, to your soul is wisdom.

|  [24:15] Lie not in wait for the home of the just,
|    and do not assail his dwelling-place;
|  [24:16] for the just, though he fall seven times, will rise,
|    but the wicked will stumble to ruin.

|  [24:17] At the fall of your foe rejoice not,
|    and do not exult at his overthrow;
|  [24:18] lest the Lord be displeased when he sees it,
|    and turn His anger away from him.

|  [24:19] Be not fretful because of evil-doers.
|    nor envious of the wicked;
|  [24:20] for the bad man will have no future.
|    The lamp of the wicked is quenched.

|  [24:21] Fear the Lord, my son, and the king,
|    be not haughty to one or the other;
|  [24:22] for swift is the ruin they raise,
|    the disaster they send unforeseen.

##### Appendix to the Second Collection of Proverbs #####

[24:23] These also belong to the wise men:

|  It is wrong to be partial in giving of judgment.
|  [24:24] All men will curse and all people will execrate
|    him who pronounces the guilty man innocent.
|  [24:25] But those whose decisions are just will fare pleasantly;
|    blessings of fortune will rest upon them.

|  [24:26] As one who kisses the lips
|    is he who returns a straight answer.

|  [24:27] Set your business in order without,
|    make all ready in your fields:
|    after that you may build up your house.

|  [24:28] Bear not false witness against your neighbour,
|    nor let your lips be deceitful.
|  [24:29] Do not threaten to treat him as he treated you,
|    and to visit his deed with retribution.

###### On the Sluggard ######

|  [24:30] By the field of the sluggard I passed.
|    by the vineyard of one that was foolish.
|  [24:31] It was all overgrown with thistles;
|    its surface was covered with nettles;
|    its wall of stone was in ruins.
|  [24:32] As I looked, I thought upon it,
|    and I drew from the sight a lesson.
|  [24:33] “Just a little more sleep, a little more slumber,
|    a little more lying with folded hands.”
|  [24:34] So will poverty come upon you like a robber,
|    and want like an armed man.

 [Proverbs 25] 

##### Third Collection of Proverbs #####

[25:1] These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, copied out.

|  [25:2] The glory of God is his mystery,
|    but the glory of kings is investigation.
|  [25:3] Like the height of the heavens and the depth of the earth,
|    so the purpose of kings is unsearchable.

|  [25:4] Remove the dross from silver,
|    and forth it comes pure altogether.
|  [25:5] Remove wicked men from the king.
|    and his throne is established by righteousness.

|  [25:6] In the presence of a king claim not honour,
|    nor stand in the place of the great.
|  [25:7] Better be told, “Come up hither,”
|    than be humbled before the prince.

|  [25:8] Do not hastily bring up a law-suit
|    of something your eyes have seen.
|  For what will you do in the end,
|    when your neighbour has put you to shame?
|  [25:9] Discuss the affair with your neighbour,
|    reveal not his secret to others;
|  [25:10] lest those that have heard it reproach you
|    and your infamy pass not away.

|  [25:11] Like apples of gold in carvings of silver
|    is a word that is fittingly spoken.
|  [25:12] Like an earring of gold and a necklace of fine gold
|    is a wise man’s reproof to a listening ear.
|  [25:13] Like a drink cooled by snow in the time of harvest
|    is a faithful envoy to those that send him:
|    he refreshes the soul of his master.
|  [25:14] As clouds and wind that yet bring no rain,
|    so is one that boasts of gifts that he gives not.
|  [25:15] An angry man can be won by forbearance,
|    and bones can be broken by gentle words.
|  [25:16] If you find honey, eat just what you need.
|    lest, after a surfeit, you vomit it up.
|  [25:17] In the house of your friend let your foot be but seldom,
|    lest, sated with you, he detest you.
|  [25:18] One who bears false witness against his neighbour
|    is a hammer, a sword, and a sharp-pointed arrow.
|  [25:19] In a crumbling tooth and a foot unsteady
|    is the faithless man’s trust in the day of distress.
|  [25:20] As vinegar to a wound
|    is a song to a sorrowful heart.
|  [25:21] Give your enemy food, if he hunger;
|    and water, if he be thirsty:
|  [25:22] for so will you heap coals of fire on his head,
|    and the Lord will give you recompense.
|  [25:23] As the north wind brings forth rain,
|    so slander an angry countenance.
|  [25:24] It is better to live on the roof in a corner
|    than in a spacious house with a quarrelsome woman.
|  [25:25] Like cool water to one that is weary
|    is good news from a distant land.
