But then, I know that there are people who are harassing you, and who want to pervert the good news of the Christ.[1:8] Yet even if we – or if an angel from heaven were to tell you any other ‘good news’ than that which we told you, may he be accursed![1:9] We have said it before, and I repeat it now – If anyone tells you a ‘good news’ other than that which you received, may he be accursed!

[1:10] Is this, I ask, trying to conciliate people, or God? Am I seeking to please people? If I were still trying to please people, I should not be a servant of Christ.

##### The Independence of the Apostle’s Gospel #####

[1:11] I remind you, friends, that the good news which I told is no mere human invention.[1:12] I, at least, did not receive it from any human being, nor was I taught it, but it came to me through a revelation made by Jesus Christ.

[1:13] You heard, no doubt, of my conduct when I was devoted to Judaism – how I persecuted the church of God to an extent beyond belief, and made havoc of it,[1:14] and how, in my devotion to Judaism, I surpassed many of my contemporaries among my own people in my intense earnestness in upholding the traditions of my ancestors.[1:15] But when God, who had set me apart even before my birth, and who called me by his love,[1:16] saw fit to reveal his Son in me, so that I might tell the good news of him among the Gentiles, then at once, instead of consulting any human being,[1:17] or even going up to Jerusalem to see those who were apostles before me, I went to Arabia, and came back again to Damascus.[1:18] Three years afterward I went up to Jerusalem to make the acquaintance of Peter, and I stayed a fortnight with him.[1:19] I did not, however, see any other apostle, except James, the Master’s brother.[1:20] (As to what I am now writing to you, I call God to witness that I am speaking the truth).[1:21] Afterward I went to the districts of Syria and Cilicia.[1:22] But I was still unknown even by sight to the Christian churches in Judea;[1:23] all that they had heard was – ‘The man who once persecuted us is now telling the good news of the faith of which he once made havoc.’[1:24] And they praised God for my sake.

 [Galatians 2] 

[2:1] Fourteen years afterward I went up to Jerusalem again with Barnabas, and I took Titus also with me.[2:2] It was in obedience to a revelation that I went; and I laid before the apostles the good news that I am proclaiming among the Gentiles. I did this privately before those who are thought highly of because I was afraid that I might possibly be taking, or might have already taken, a course which would prove useless.[2:3] Yet even my companion, Titus, though a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised.[2:4] But, because of those who pretended to be followers who had stolen in, the intruders who had crept in to spy on the liberty which we have through union with Christ Jesus, in order to bring us back to slavery –[2:5] Why, we did not for a moment yield submission to them, so that the truth of the good news might be yours always![2:6] Of those who are thought somewhat highly of – what they once were makes no difference to me; God does not recognize human distinctions – those, I say, who are thought highly of added nothing to my message.[2:7] On the contrary, they saw that I had been entrusted with the good news for the Gentiles, just as Peter had been for the Jews.[2:8] For he who gave Peter power for his mission to the Jews gave me, also, power to go to the Gentiles.[2:9] Recognizing the charge entrusted to me, James, Peter, and John, who were regarded as pillars of the church, openly acknowledged Barnabas and me as fellow workers, agreeing that we should go to the Gentiles, and they to the Jews.[2:10] Only we were to remember the poor – the thing I was myself anxious to do.[2:11] But, when Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face; for he stood self-condemned.[2:12] Before certain persons came from James, he had been in the habit of eating with the Gentile converts; but, when they came, he began to withdraw and hold aloof, because he was afraid of offending those who still held to circumcision.[2:13] The rest of the Jewish converts were guilty of the same hypocrisy, so that even Barnabas was led away by it.[2:14] But, when I saw that they were not dealing straightforwardly with the truth of the good news, I said to Peter, before them all, “If you, who were born a Jew, adopt Gentile customs, instead of Jewish, why are you trying to compel the Gentile converts to adopt Jewish customs?”

##### The Law and the Gospel #####

[2:15] We, though we are Jews by birth and not outcasts of Gentile origin, know that no one is pronounced righteous as the result of obedience to Law, but only through faith in Christ Jesus.[2:16] So we placed our faith in Christ Jesus, in order that we might be pronounced righteous, as the result of faith in Christ, and not of obedience to Law; for such obedience will not result in even one soul’s being pronounced righteous.[2:17] If, while seeking to be pronounced righteous through union with Christ, we were ourselves seen to be outcasts, would that make Christ an agent of sin? Heaven forbid![2:18] For, if I rebuild the things that I pulled down, I prove myself to have done wrong.[2:19] I, indeed, through Law became dead to Law, in order to live for God.[2:20] I have been crucified with Christ. So it is no longer I that live, but it is Christ who lives in me; and, as for my present earthly life, I am living it by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave himself for me.[2:21] I do not reject the love of God. If righteousness comes through Law, then there was no need for Christ to die!

 [Galatians 3] 


[3:1] Foolish Galatians! Who has been fascinating you – you before whose eyes Jesus Christ was depicted on the cross?[3:2] Here is the one thing that I want to find out from you – Did you receive the Spirit as the result of obedience to Law, or of your having listened with faith?[3:3] Can you be so foolish? After beginning with what is spiritual, do you now end with what is external?[3:4] Did you go through so much to no purpose? – if indeed it really was to no purpose![3:5] He who supplies you abundantly with his Spirit and endows you with such powers – does he do this as the result of obedience to Law? Or as the result of your having listened with faith?[3:6] It is just as it was with Abraham –

|  he had faith in God, and his faith was regarded by God as righteousness.

[3:7] You see, then, that those whose lives are based on faith are the sons of Abraham.[3:8] And scripture, foreseeing that God would pronounce the Gentiles righteous as the result of faith, foretold the good news to Abraham in the words –

|  ‘Through you all the Gentiles will be blessed.’

[3:9] And, therefore, those whose lives are based on faith share the blessings bestowed on the faith of Abraham.[3:10] All who rely on obedience to Law are under a curse, for scripture says –

|  ‘Cursed is everyone who does not abide by all that is written in the book of the Law, and do it.’

[3:11] Again, it is evident that no one is pronounced righteous before God through Law, for we read –

|  ‘Through faith the righteous will find life.’

[3:12] But the Law is not based on faith; no, its words are –

|  ‘Those who practice these precepts will find life through them.’

[3:13] Christ ransomed us from the curse pronounced in the Law, by taking the curse on himself for us, for scripture says –

|  ‘Cursed is anyone who is hanged on a tree.’

[3:14] And this he did that the blessing given to Abraham might be extended to the Gentiles through their union with Jesus Christ; that so, through our faith, we also might receive the promised gift of the Spirit.

[3:15] To take an illustration, friends, from daily life – No one sets aside even an agreement between two people, when once it has been confirmed, nor do they add conditions to it.[3:16] Now it was to Abraham that the promises were made, ‘and to his offspring.’ It was not said ‘to his offsprings,’ as if many persons were meant, but the words were ‘to your offspring,’ showing that one person was meant – and that was Christ.[3:17] My point is this – An agreement already confirmed by God cannot be canceled by the Law, which came four hundred and thirty years later, so as to cause the promise to be set aside.[3:18] If our heritage is the result of Law, then it has ceased to be the result of a promise. Yet God conferred it on Abraham by a promise.

[3:19] What, then, you ask, was the use of the Law? It was a later addition, to make people conscious of their wrong-doings, and intended to last only until the coming of that offspring to whom the promise had been made; and it was delivered through angels by a mediator.[3:20] Now mediation implies more than one person, but God is one only.[3:21] Does that set the Law in opposition to God’s promises? Heaven forbid! For, if a Law had been given capable of bestowing life, then righteousness would have actually owed its existence to Law.[3:22] But the words of scripture represent the whole world as being in bondage to sin, so that the promised blessing, dependent, as it is, on faith in Jesus Christ, may be given to those who have faith in him.

[3:23] Before the coming of faith, we were kept under the guard of the Law, in bondage, awaiting the faith that was destined to be revealed.[3:24] Thus the Law has proved a guide to lead us to Christ, in order that we may be pronounced righteous as the result of faith.[3:25] But now that faith has come we no longer need a guide.

[3:26] For you are all sons of God, through your faith in Christ Jesus.[3:27] For all of you who were baptized into union with Christ clothed yourselves with Christ.[3:28] All distinctions between Jew and Greek, slave and free, male and female, have vanished; for in union with Christ Jesus you are all one.[3:29] And, since you belong to Christ, it follows that you are Abraham’s offspring and, under the promise, sharers in the inheritance.

 [Galatians 4] 

[4:1] My point is this – As long as the heir is under age, there is no difference between him and a slave, though he is master of the whole estate.[4:2] He is subject to the control of guardians and stewards, during the period for which his father has power to appoint them.[4:3] And so is it with us; when we were under age, as it were, we were slaves to the puerile teaching of this world;[4:4] but, when the full time came, God sent his Son – born a woman’s child, born subject to Law –[4:5] To ransom those who were subject to Law, so that we might take our position as sons.

[4:6] And it is because you are sons that God sent into our hearts the Spirit of his Son, with the cry – ‘Abba, our Father.’[4:7] You, therefore, are no longer a slave, but a son; and, if a son, then an heir also, by God’s appointment.

[4:8] Yet formerly, in your ignorance of God, you became slaves to ‘gods’ which were no gods.[4:9] But now that you have found God – or, rather, have been found by him – how is it that you are turning back to that poor and feeble puerile teaching, to which yet once again you are wanting to become slaves?[4:10] You are scrupulous in keeping days and months and seasons and years![4:11] You make me fear that the labor which I have spent on you may have been wasted.

[4:12] I entreat you, friends, to become like me, as I became like you. You have never done me any wrong.[4:13] You remember that it was owing to bodily infirmity that on the first occasion I told you the good news.[4:14] And as for what must have tried you in my condition, it did not inspire you with scorn or disgust, but you welcomed me as if I had been an angel of God – or Christ Jesus himself![4:15] What has become then, of your blessings? For I can bear witness that, had it been possible, you would have torn out your eyes and given them to me![4:16] Am I to think, then, that I have become your enemy by telling you the truth?[4:17] Certain people are seeking your favor, but with no honorable object. No, indeed, they want to isolate you, so that you will have to seek their favor.[4:18] It is always honorable to have your favor sought in an honorable cause, and not only when I am with you, my dear children –[4:19] you for whom I am again enduring a mother’s pains, until a likeness to Christ will have been formed in you.[4:20] But I could wish to be with you now and speak in a different tone, for I am perplexed about you.

[4:21] Tell me, you who want to be still subject to Law – Why don’t you listen to the Law?[4:22] Scripture says that Abraham had two sons, one the child of the slave-woman and the other the child of the free woman.[4:23] But the child of the slave-woman was born in the course of nature, while the child of the free woman was born in fulfillment of a promise.[4:24] This story may be taken as an allegory. The women stand for two Covenants. One covenant, given from Mount Sinai, produces a race of slaves and is represented by Hagar[4:25] (The word Hagar meaning in Arabia Mount Sinai) and it ranks with the Jerusalem of today, for she and her children are in slavery.[4:26] But the Jerusalem above is free, and she it is who is our mother.[4:27] For scripture says –

|  ‘Rejoice, you barren one, who does never bear,
|  Break into shouts, you who are never in labor,
|    For many are the children of her who is desolate –
|      aye, more than of her who has a husband.’

[4:28] As for ourselves, friends, we, like Isaac, are children born in fulfillment of a promise.[4:29] Yet at that time the child born in the course of nature persecuted the child born by the power of the Spirit; and it is the same now.[4:30] But what does the passage of scripture say?

|  ‘Send away the slave-woman and her son; for the slave’s son will not be coheir with the son of the free woman.’

[4:31] And so, friends, we are not children of a slave, but of her who is free.

 [Galatians 5] 

##### The Gospel in the Daily Life #####

[5:1] It is for freedom that Christ set us free; stand firm therefore, and do not again be held under the yoke of slavery.

[5:2] Understand that I, Paul, myself tell you that if you allow yourselves to be circumcised, Christ will avail you nothing.[5:3] I again declare to everyone who receives circumcision, that he binds himself to obey the whole Law.[5:4] You have severed yourselves from Christ – you who are seeking to be pronounced righteous through Law; you have fallen away from love.[5:5] For we, by the help of the Spirit, are eagerly waiting for the fulfillment of our hope – that we may be pronounced righteous as the result of faith.[5:6] If we are in union with Christ Jesus, neither is circumcision nor the omission of it anything, but faith, working through love, is everything.[5:7] You were once making good progress! Who has hindered you from obeying the truth?[5:8] The persuasion brought to bear on you does not come from him who calls you.[5:9] A little leaven leavens all the dough.[5:10] I, through my union with the Lord, am persuaded that you will learn to think with me. But the man who is disturbing your minds will have to bear his punishment, whoever he may be.[5:11] If I, friends, am still proclaiming circumcision, why am I still persecuted? It seems that the cross has ceased to be an obstacle![5:12] I could even wish that the people who are unsettling you would go further still and mutilate themselves.

[5:13] Remember, friends, to you the call came to give you freedom. Only do not make your freedom an opportunity for self-indulgence, but serve one another in a loving spirit.[5:14] Indeed, the whole Law has been summed up in this one precept –

|  ‘You must love your neighbor as you love yourself.’

[5:15] But, if you are continually wounding and preying on one another, take care that you are not destroyed by one another.

[5:16] This is what I have to say – Let your steps be guided by the Spirit, and then you will never gratify the cravings of your earthly nature.[5:17] For these cravings of our earthly nature conflict with the Spirit, and the Spirit with our earthly nature – they are two contrary principles – so that you cannot do what you wish.[5:18] But, if you follow the guidance of the Spirit, you are not subject to Law.[5:19] The sins of our earthly nature are unmistakable. They are sins like these – sexual immorality, impurity, indecency,[5:20] idolatry, sorcery, quarrels, strife, jealousy, outbursts of passion, rivalries, dissensions, divisions,[5:21] feelings of envy, drunkenness, revelry, and the like. And I warn you, as I warned you before, that those who indulge in such things will have no place in the kingdom of God.[5:22] But the fruit produced by the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindliness, generosity, trustfulness, gentleness, self-control.[5:23] Against such things there is no law![5:24] And those who belong to Jesus, the Christ, have already crucified their earthly nature, with its passions and its cravings.

[5:25] Since our life is due to the Spirit, let us rule our conduct also by the Spirit.[5:26] Do not let us grow vain, and provoke or envy one another.

 [Galatians 6] 

[6:1] My friends, even if someone should be caught committing a sin, you who are spiritually minded should, in a gentle spirit, help them to recover themselves, taking care that you yourselves are not tempted.[6:2] Bear one another’s burdens, and so carry out the Law of the Christ.[6:3] If a person imagines themselves to be somebody, when they are really nobody, they deceive themselves.[6:4] Let everyone test their own work, and then their cause for satisfaction will be in themselves and not in a comparison with their neighbor;[6:5] for everyone must bear their own load.[6:6] The person, however, who is being instructed in the message ought always to share their blessings with their teacher.

[6:7] Do not be deceived. God cannot be mocked. What a person sows that they will reap.[6:8] For the person who sows the field of their earthly nature will from that earthly nature reap corruption; while the one who sows the field of the spirit will from that spirit reap eternal life.[6:9] Let us never tire of doing right, for at the proper season we will reap our harvest, if we do not grow weary.[6:10] Therefore, I say, as the opportunity occurs, let us treat everyone with kindness, and especially members of the Household of the faith.

##### Conclusion in the Apostle’s own handwriting #####

[6:11] See in what large letters I am writing with my own hand.[6:12] Those who wish to appear to advantage in regard to outward observances are the people who are trying to compel you to be circumcised; and they do it only to avoid being persecuted for the cross of Jesus, the Christ.[6:13] Even these men who are circumcised do not themselves keep the Law; yet they want you to be circumcised, so that they may boast of your observance of the rite.[6:14] But, for my part, may I never boast of anything except the cross of Jesus Christ, our Master, through whom the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.[6:15] For neither is circumcision nor the omission of it anything; but a new nature is everything.[6:16] May all who rule their conduct by this principle find peace and mercy – they who are the Israel of God.

[6:17] For the future let no one trouble me; for I bear the marks of Jesus branded on my body.

[6:18] May the blessing of Jesus Christ, our Lord, rest on your souls, friends. Amen.


Paul’s Letter to the
--------------------

Ephesians
=========

 [Ephesians 1] 

##### Introduction #####

[1:1] To Christ’s people at Ephesus who are faithful to him, from Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus, by the will of God.[1:2] May God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you and give you peace.

[1:3] Blessed is the God and Father of Jesus Christ, our Lord, who has blessed us on high with every spiritual blessing, in Christ.[1:4] For he chose us in our union with Christ before the creation of the universe, so that we might be holy and blameless in his sight, living in the spirit of love.[1:5] From the first he destined us, in his goodwill towards us, to be adopted as sons through Jesus Christ,[1:6] and so to enhance that glorious manifestation of his loving kindness which he gave us in the one he loves;[1:7] for in him, and through the shedding of his blood, we have found redemption in the pardon of our offenses.[1:8] All this accords with the loving kindness which God lavished on us, accompanied by countless gifts of wisdom and discernment,[1:9] when he made known to us his hidden purpose. And it also accords with the goodwill which God purposed to exhibit in Christ,[1:10] in view of that divine order which was to mark the completion of the ages, when he should make everything, both in heaven and on earth, centre in him.[1:11] In him, I say, for by our union with him we became God’s heritage, having from the first been destined for this in the intention of him who, in all that happens, is carrying out his own fixed purpose;[1:12] that we should enhance his glory – we who have been the first to rest our hopes on the Christ.[1:13] And you, too, by your union with him, after you had heard the message of the truth, the good news of your salvation – you believed in him and were sealed as his by receiving the holy Spirit, which he had promised.[1:14] And the Spirit is a pledge of our future heritage, foreshadowing the full redemption of God’s own people – to enhance his glory.

##### The power of God displayed in Christ, the Head of the Church #####

[1:15] And therefore I, ever since I heard of the faith in the Lord Jesus which prevails among you, and of your confidence in all Christ’s people,[1:16] have never omitted to thank God on your behalf, whenever I make mention of you in my prayers.[1:17] My prayer is that the God of Jesus Christ our Lord, the all-glorious Father, may inspire you with wisdom and true insight through a fuller knowledge of himself;[1:18] that your minds may be so enlightened that you may realize the hope given by God’s call, the wealth of the glory of his heritage among Christ’s people,[1:19] and the transcendent greatness of the power which he is able to exercise in dealing with us who believe in him.[1:20] The same mighty power was exerted on the Christ, when he raised the Christ from the dead and ‘caused him to sit at his right hand’ on high, exalting him above all angels and archangels of every rank,[1:21] and above every name that can be named, whether in the present age, or in the age to come.[1:22] And God placed all things under Christ’s feet, and gave him to the church as its supreme head;[1:23] for the church is Christ’s body, and is filled by him who fills all things everywhere with his presence.

 [Ephesians 2] 

[2:1] You yourselves were once dead because of your offenses and sins.[2:2] For at one time you lived in sin, following the ways of the world, in subjection to the Ruler of the powers of the air – the Spirit who is still at work among the disobedient.[2:3] And it was among them that we all once lived our lives, indulging the cravings of our earthly nature, and carrying out the desires prompted by that earthly nature and by our own thoughts. Our nature exposed us to the divine wrath, like the rest of humanity.[2:4] Yet God, in his abundant compassion, and because of the great love with which he loved us,[2:5] even though we were dead because of our offenses, gave life to us in giving life to the Christ. (By God’s loving kindness you have been saved.)[2:6] And, through our union with Christ Jesus, God raised us with him, and caused us to sit with him on high,[2:7] in order that, by his goodness to us in Christ Jesus, he might display in the ages to come the boundless wealth of his loving kindness.[2:8] For it is by God’s loving kindness that you have been saved, through your faith. It is not due to yourselves; the gift is God’s.[2:9] It is not due to obedience to Law, so that no one can boast.[2:10] For we are God’s handiwork, created, by our union with Christ Jesus, for the good actions in doing which God had pre-arranged that we should spend our lives.

[2:11] Remember, therefore, that you were once Gentiles yourselves, as your bodies showed; you were called ‘the Uncircumcised’ by those who were called ‘the Circumcised’ – circumcised only by human hands![2:12] Remember that you were at that time far from Christ; you were shut out from the citizenship of Israel; you were strangers to the Covenants founded on God’s Promise; you were in the world without hope and without God.[2:13] But now, through your union with Christ Jesus, you who once were far off have, by the shedding of the blood of the Christ, been brought near.[2:14] He it is who is our peace. He made the two divisions of humanity one, broke down the barrier that separated them,[2:15] and in his human nature put an end to the cause of enmity between them – the Law with its injunctions and ordinances – in order to create, through union with himself, from Jew and Gentile, one new humanity and so make peace.[2:16] And when, on the cross, he had destroyed their mutual enmity, he sought by means of his cross to reconcile them both to God, united in one body.[2:17] He came with the good news of peace for you who were far off, and of peace for those who were near;[2:18] for it is through him that we, the Jews and the Gentiles, united in the one Spirit, are now able to approach the Father.[2:19] It follows, then, that you are no longer strangers and aliens, but are fellow citizens with Christ’s people and members of God’s Household.[2:20] You have been built up on the foundation laid by the apostles and prophets, Christ Jesus himself being the corner-stone.[2:21] United in him, every part of the building, closely joined together, will grow into a Temple, consecrated by its union with the Lord.[2:22] And, through union in him, you also are being built up together, to be a place where God lives through the Spirit.

 [Ephesians 3] 

##### The Apostle’s Divine Commission to the Gentiles #####

[3:1] For this reason I, Paul, the prisoner of Jesus, the Christ, for the sake of you Gentiles –[3:2] For you have heard, I suppose, of the responsible charge with which God entrusted me for your benefit,[3:3] and also that it was by direct revelation that the hidden purpose of God was made known to me, as I have already briefly told you.[3:4] And, by reading what I have written, you will be able to judge how far I understand this hidden purpose of God in Christ.[3:5] In former generations it was not made known to humanity, as fully as it has now been revealed by the Spirit to the apostles and prophets among Christ’s people –[3:6] That, by union with Christ Jesus and through the good news, the Gentiles are coheirs with us and members of one body, and that they share with us in God’s Promise.[3:7] Of this good news I become an assistant, in virtue of the charge with which God entrusted me in the exercise of his power –[3:8] Yes, to me, who am less than the least of all Christ’s people, was this charge entrusted! – to tell the Gentiles the good news of the boundless wealth to be found in the Christ,[3:9] and to make clear what is God’s way of working out that hidden purpose which from the first has been concealed in the mind of the Creator of all things;[3:10] so that now to the archangels and to all the powers on high should be made known, through the church, the all-embracing wisdom of God,[3:11] in accordance with that purpose which runs through all the ages and which he has now accomplished in Jesus, the Christ, our Master.[3:12] And in union with him, and through our trust in him, we find courage to approach God with confidence.[3:13] Therefore I beg you not to be disheartened at the sufferings that I am undergoing for your sakes; for they redound to your honor.[3:14] For this reason, then, I kneel before the Father –[3:15] from whom all ‘fatherhood’ in heaven and on earth derives its name –[3:16] And pray that, in proportion to the wealth of his glory, he will strengthen you with his power by breathing his Spirit into your inmost soul,[3:17] so that the Christ, through your faith, may make his home within your hearts in love; And I pray that you, now firmly rooted and established, may, with all Christ’s people,[3:18] have the power to comprehend in all its width and length and height and depth,[3:19] and to understand – though it surpasses all understanding – the love of the Christ; and so be filled to the full with God himself.

[3:20] To him who, through his power which is at work within us, is able to do far more than anything that we can ask or conceive –[3:21] To him be all glory through the church and through Christ Jesus, for all generations, age after age. Amen.

 [Ephesians 4] 

##### The Gospel and Daily Life #####

[4:1] I beg you, then – I who am a prisoner in the Master’s cause – to live lives worthy of the call that you have received;[4:2] always humble and gentle, patient, bearing lovingly with one another,[4:3] and striving to maintain in the bond of peace the unity given by the Spirit.[4:4] There is but one body and one Spirit, just as there was but one hope set before you when you received your call.[4:5] There is but one Lord, one faith, one baptism.[4:6] There is but one God and Father of all – the God who is over all, pervades all, and is in all.[4:7] Everyone of us, however, has been entrusted with some charge, each in accordance with the extent of the gift of the Christ.[4:8] That is why it is said –

|  ‘When he went up on high, he led his captives into captivity. And gave gifts to humanity.’

[4:9] Now surely this ‘going up’ must imply that he had already gone down into the world beneath.[4:10] He who went down is the same as he who went up – up beyond the highest heaven, so that he might fill all things with his presence.[4:11] And he it is who gave to the church apostles, prophets, missionaries, pastors, and teachers,[4:12] to fit his people for the work of the ministry, for the building up of the body of the Christ.[4:13] And this will continue, until we all attain to that unity which is given by faith and by a fuller knowledge of the Son of God; until we reach maturity – the full standard of the perfection of the Christ.[4:14] Then we will no longer be like infants, tossed backward and forward, blown about by every breath of human teaching and by people’s trickery and craftiness;[4:15] but holding the truth in a spirit of love, we will grow into complete union with him who is our head – Christ himself.[4:16] For from him the whole body, closely joined and knit together by the contact of every part with the source of its life, derives its power to grow, in proportion to the vigour of each individual part; and so is being built up in a spirit of love.

[4:17] This, then, as one in union with the Lord, I implore: Do not continue to live such purposeless lives as the Gentiles live,[4:18] with their powers of discernment darkened, cut off from the life of God, owing to the ignorance that prevails among them and to the hardness of their hearts.[4:19] Lost to all sense of shame, they have abandoned themselves to licentiousness, in order to practice every kind of impurity without restraint.[4:20] But far different is the lesson you learned from the Christ – if, that is, you really listened to him,[4:21] and through union with him were taught the truth, as it is to be found in Jesus.[4:22] For you learned with regard to your former way of living that you must cast off your old nature, which, yielding to deluding passions, grows corrupt;[4:23] that the spirit of your minds must be constantly renewed;[4:24] and that you must clothe yourselves in that new nature which was created to resemble God, with the righteousness and holiness springing from the truth.

[4:25] Since, therefore, you have cast off what is false, you must every one of you speak the truth to your neighbors. For we are united to one another like the parts of a body.[4:26] Be angry, yet do not sin. Do not let the sun go down on your anger;[4:27] and give no opportunity to the devil.[4:28] Let the person who steals steal no longer, but rather they should toil with their hands at honest work, so that they may have something to share with anyone in need.[4:29] Never let any foul word pass your lips, but only such good words as the occasion demands, so that they may be a help to those who hear them.[4:30] And do not grieve God’s Holy Spirit; for it was through that Spirit that God sealed you as his, against the day of redemption.[4:31] Let all bitterness, passion, anger, brawling, and abusive language be banished from among you, as well as all malice.[4:32] Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, ready to forgive one another, just as God, in Christ, forgave you.

 [Ephesians 5] 

[5:1] Therefore imitate God, as his dear children,[5:2] and live a life of love, following the example of the Christ, who loved you and gave himself for you as an offering and a sacrifice to God, that should be fragrant and acceptable.

[5:3] As for sexual immorality and every kind of impurity, or greed, do not let them even be mentioned among you, as befits Christ’s people,[5:4] nor shameful conduct, nor foolish talk or jesting, for they are wholly out of place among you; but rather thanksgiving.[5:5] For of this you may be sure – that no one who is unchaste or impure or greedy of gain (for to be greedy of gain is idolatry) has any place awaiting him in the kingdom of the Christ and God.

[5:6] Do not let anyone deceive you with specious arguments. Those are the sins that bring down the wrath of God on the disobedient.[5:7] Therefore have nothing to do with such people.[5:8] For, although you were once in darkness, now, by your union with the Lord, you are in the light. Live as children of light –[5:9] for the outcome of life in the light may be seen in every form of goodness, righteousness, and sincerity –[5:10] always trying to find out what is pleasing to the Lord.[5:11] Take no part in deeds of darkness, from which no good can come; on the contrary, expose them.[5:12] It is degrading even to speak of the things continually done by them in secret.[5:13] All such actions, when exposed, have their true character made manifest by the light.[5:14] For everything that has its true character made manifest is clear as light. And that is why it is said –

|  ‘Sleeper, awake!
|  Arise from the dead,
|    And the Christ will give you light!’

[5:15] Take great care, then, how you live – not unwisely but wisely,[5:16] making the most of every opportunity; for these are evil days.[5:17] Therefore do not grow thoughtless, but try to understand what the Lord’s will is.[5:18] Do not drink wine to excess, for that leads to profligacy; but seek to be filled with the Spirit of God, and speak to one another in psalms and hymns and sacred songs.[5:19] Sing and make music in your hearts to the Lord.[5:20] Always give thanks for everything to our God and Father, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

[5:21] Submit to one another because you honor and respect Christ.

[5:22] Wives should submit to their husbands as submitting to the Lord.[5:23] For a man is the head of his wife, as the Christ is the head of the church – being indeed himself the Savior of his body.[5:24] But as the church submits to the Christ, so also should wives submit to their husbands in everything.[5:25] Husbands, love your wives, just as the Christ loved the church, and gave himself for her,[5:26] to make her holy, after purifying her by the washing with the water, according to his promise;[5:27] so that he might himself bring the church, in all her beauty, into his own presence, with no spot or wrinkle or blemish of any kind, but that she might be holy and faultless.[5:28] That is how husbands ought to love their wives – as if they were their own bodies. A man who loves his wife is really loving himself;[5:29] for no one ever yet hated his own body. But everyone feeds his body and cares for it, just as the Christ for the church;[5:30] for we are members of his body.

|  [5:31] For this cause a man will leave his father and mother, and be united to his wife; and the man and his wife will become one.

[5:32] In this there is a profound truth – I am speaking of Christ and his church.[5:33] However, for you individually, let each love his wife as if she were himself; and the wife be careful to respect her husband.

 [Ephesians 6] 

[6:1] Children, obey your parents, as children of the Lord; for that is but right.[6:2] ‘Honor your father and mother’ – this is the first Commandment with a promise –[6:3] ‘so that you may prosper and have a long life on earth.’[6:4] And fathers, do not irritate your children, but bring them up with Christian discipline and instruction.

[6:5] Slaves, obey your earthly masters, with anxious care, giving them ungrudging service, as if obeying the Christ;[6:6] not only when their eyes are on you, as if you had merely to please people, but as slaves of Christ, who are trying to carry out the will of God.[6:7] Give your service heartily and cheerfully, as working for the Master and not for people;[6:8] for you know that everyone will be rewarded by the Master for any honest work that he has done, whether he is a slave or free.[6:9] And masters, treat your slaves in the same spirit. Give up threatening them; for you know that he who is both their Master and yours is in heaven, and that before him there is no distinction of rank.

[6:10] For the future, find strength in your union with the Lord, and in the power which comes from his might.[6:11] Put on the full armor of God, so that you may be able to stand your ground against the stratagems of the devil.[6:12] For ours is no struggle against enemies of flesh and blood, but against all the various powers of evil that hold sway in the darkness around us, against the spirits of wickedness on high.[6:13] Therefore take up the full armor of God, so that when the evil day comes, you may be able to withstand the attack, and, having fought to the end, still to stand your ground.[6:14] Stand your ground, then, with truth for your belt, and with righteousness for your breast-plate,[6:15] and with the readiness to serve the good news of peace as shoes for your feet.[6:16] At every onslaught take up faith for your shield; for with it you will be able to extinguish all the flaming darts of the evil one.[6:17] And receive the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit – which is the message of God – always with prayer and supplication.[6:18] Pray in spirit at all times. Be intent on this, with unwearying perseverance and supplication for all Christ’s people –[6:19] and on my behalf also, so that when I begin to speak, words may be given me, so that I may fearlessly make known the inmost truth of the good news,[6:20] on behalf of which I am an ambassador – in chains! Pray that, in telling it, I may speak fearlessly as I ought.

##### Conclusion #####

[6:21] To enable you, as well as others, to know all that concerns me and what I am doing, Tychicus, our dear friend and faithful helper in the Master’s cause, will tell you everything.[6:22] I am sending him to you on purpose that you may learn all about us, and that he may cheer your hearts.

[6:23] May God, the Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ give every follower peace, and love linked with faith.[6:24] May God’s blessing be with all who love our Lord Jesus Christ with an undying love.


Paul’s Letter to the
--------------------

Philippians
===========

 [Philippians 1] 

[1:1] To all Christ’s people at Philippi, with the supervisors and assistants, from Paul and Timothy, servants of Christ Jesus.[1:2] May God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you, and give you peace.[1:3] Every recollection that I have of you is a cause of thankfulness to God,[1:4] always, in every prayer that I offer for you all – my prayers are full of joy –[1:5] Because of the share that you have had in spreading the good news, from the first day that you received it until now.[1:6] For of this I am confident, that he who began a good work in you will complete it in readiness for the day of Jesus Christ.[1:7] And, indeed, I am justified in feeling like this about you all; because you have a warm place in my heart – you who all, both in my imprisonment and in the work of defending and establishing the good news, shared my privilege with me.[1:8] God will bear me witness how I yearn over you all with the tenderness of Christ Jesus.[1:9] And what I pray for is this – that your love may grow yet stronger and stronger, with increasing knowledge and all discernment,[1:10] until you are able to appreciate all moral distinctions. And I pray, too, that you may be kept pure and blameless against the day of Christ,[1:11] bearing a rich harvest of that righteousness which comes through Jesus Christ, to the glory and praise of God.

[1:12] Friends, I want you to realize that what has happened to me has actually served to forward the good news.[1:13] It has even become evident, not only to all the imperial guard, but to everyone else, that it is for Christ’s sake that I am in chains.[1:14] And besides this, most of our fellow followers have gained confidence in the Lord through my chains, and now venture with far greater freedom to speak of God’s message fearlessly.[1:15] It is true that some do proclaim the Christ out of Jealousy and opposition; but there are others who proclaim him from goodwill.[1:16] The latter do it from love for me, knowing that I have been appointed to plead the cause of the good news.[1:17] The former spread the news of the Christ in a factious spirit, and not sincerely, thinking to add to the pain of my chains.[1:18] But what of that? Only that in some way or other, either with assumed or with real earnestness, Christ is being made known; and at that I rejoice.[1:19] Yes, and I will rejoice, for I know that, through your prayers and through a rich supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ, all this will make for my salvation.[1:20] And this will fulfill my earnest expectation and hope that I will have no cause for shame, but that, with unfailing courage, now as hitherto, Christ will be honored in my body, whether by my life or by my death,[1:21] for to me life is Christ, and death is gain.[1:22] But what if the life here in the body – if this brings me fruit from my labors? Then which to choose I cannot tell! I am sorely perplexed either way![1:23] My own desire is to depart and be with Christ, for this would be far better.[1:24] But, for your sakes, it may be more needful that I should still remain here in the body.[1:25] Yes, I am confident that this is so, and therefore I am sure that I will stay, and stay near you all, to promote your progress and joy in the faith;[1:26] so that, when you once more have me among you, you, in your union with Christ Jesus, may find in me fresh cause for exultation.[1:27] Under all circumstances let your lives be worthy of the good news of the Christ: so that, whether I come and see you, or whether I hear of your affairs at a distance, I may know that you are standing firm, animated by one spirit, and joining with one heart in a common struggle for the faith taught by the good news,[1:28] without ever shrinking from your opponents. To them this will be a sign of their destruction and of your salvation – a sign from God.[1:29] For, on behalf of Christ, you have had the privilege granted you, not only of trusting in him, but also of suffering on his behalf.[1:30] You will be engaged in the same hard struggle as that which you once saw me waging, and which you hear that I am waging still.

 [Philippians 2] 

[2:1] If, then, any encouragement comes through union with Christ, if there is any persuasive power in love, if there is any communion with the Spirit, if there is any tenderness or pity,[2:2] I entreat you to make my happiness complete – Live together animated by the same spirit and in mutual love, one in heart, animated by one Spirit.[2:3] Nothing should be done out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility lift others up above yourselves,[2:4] considering not only your own interests but also the interests of others.[2:5] Let the spirit of Christ Jesus be yours also.[2:6] Though the divine nature was his from the beginning, yet he did not look on equality with God as above all things to be clung to,[2:7] but impoverished himself by taking the nature of a servant and becoming like one of us;[2:8] he appeared among us as a man, and still further humbled himself by submitting even to death – to death on a cross![2:9] And that is why God raised him to the very highest place, and gave him the name which stands above all other names,[2:10] so that in adoration of the name of Jesus every knee should bend, in heaven, on earth, and under the earth,[2:11] and that every tongue should acknowledge JESUS CHRIST as LORD – to the glory of God the Father.[2:12] Therefore, my dear friends, as you have always been obedient in the past, so now work out your own salvation with anxious care, not only when I am with you, but all the more now that I am absent.[2:13] Remember it is God who, in his kindness, is at work within you, enabling you both to will and to work.[2:14] In all that you do, avoid murmuring and dissension,[2:15] so as to prove yourselves blameless and innocent – faultless children of God, in the midst of an evil-disposed and perverse generation, in which you are seen shining like stars in a dark world,[2:16] offering to them the message of life; and then I will be able at the day of Christ to boast that I did not run my course for nothing, or toil for nothing.[2:17] And yet, even if, when your faith is offered as a sacrifice to God, my lifeblood must be poured out in addition, still I will rejoice and share the joy of you all;[2:18] and you must also rejoice and share my joy.[2:19] I hope, however, as one who trusts in the Lord Jesus, to send Timothy to you before long, so that I may myself be cheered by receiving news of you.[2:20] For I have no one but him to send – no one of kindred spirit who would take the same genuine interest in your welfare.[2:21] They are all pursuing their own aims and not those of Christ Jesus.[2:22] But you know what Timothy has proved himself to be, and how, like a child working for his father, he worked hard with me in spreading the good news.[2:23] It is Timothy, then, whom I hope to send, as soon as ever I can foresee how it will go with me.[2:24] And I am confident, as one who trusts in the Lord Jesus, that before long I myself will follow.[2:25] Still I think it necessary to send Epaphroditus to you now, for he is my dear friend, fellow worker, and fellow soldier, and he was also your messenger to help me in my need.[2:26] For he has been longing to see you all, and has been distressed because you heard of his illness.[2:27] And I can assure you that his illness very nearly proved fatal. But God had pity on him, and not on him only but also on me, so that I might not have sorrow on sorrow.[2:28] I am all the more ready, therefore, to send him, so that the sight of him may revive your spirits and my own sorrow be lightened.[2:29] Give him, then, the heartiest of Christian welcomes, and hold such people in great honor.[2:30] For it was owing to his devotion to the Master’s work that he was at the point of death, having risked his own life in the effort to supply what was wanting in the help that you sent me.

 [Philippians 3] 

[3:1] In conclusion, my friends, all joy be yours in your union with the Lord. To repeat what I have already written does not weary me, and is the safe course for you.[3:2] Beware of those dogs! Beware of those mischievous workers! Beware of the men who mutilate themselves![3:3] For it is we who are the circumcised – we whose worship is prompted by the Spirit of God, who exult in Christ Jesus, and who do not rely on external privileges;[3:4] though I, if anyone, have cause to rely even on them. If anyone thinks he can rely on external privileges, far more can I![3:5] I was circumcised when eight days old; I am an Israelite by birth, and of the tribe of Benjamin; I am a Hebrew, and the child of Hebrews. As to the Law, I was a Pharisee;[3:6] as to zeal, I was a persecutor of the church; as to such righteousness as is due to Law, I proved myself blameless.[3:7] But all the things which I once held to be gains I have now, for the Christ’s sake, come to count as loss.[3:8] More than that, I count everything as loss, for the sake of the exceeding value of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord. And for his sake I have lost everything, and count it as refuse, if I may but gain Christ and be found in union with him;[3:9] any righteousness that I have being, not the righteousness that results from Law, but the righteousness which comes through faith in Christ – the righteousness which is derived from God and is founded on faith.[3:10] Then indeed I will know Christ, and the power of his resurrection, and all that it means to share his sufferings,[3:11] in the hope that, if I become like him in death, I may possibly attain to the resurrection from the dead.[3:12] Not that I have already laid hold of it, or that I am already made perfect. But I press on, in the hope of actually laying hold of that for which indeed I was laid hold of by Christ Jesus.[3:13] For I, friends, do not regard myself as having yet laid hold of it. But this one thing I do – forgetting what lies behind, and straining every nerve for that which lies in front,[3:14] I press on to the goal, to gain the prize of that heavenward call which God gave me through Christ Jesus.[3:15] Let all of us, then, whose faith is mature, think this way. Then, if on any matter you think otherwise, God will make that also plain to you.[3:16] Only we are bound to order our lives by what we have already attained.

[3:17] My friends, unite in following my example, and fix your eyes on those who are living by the pattern which we have set you.[3:18] For there are many – of whom I have often told you, and now tell you even with tears – who are living in enmity to the cross of the Christ.[3:19] The end of such people is ruin; for their appetites are their God, and they glory in their shame; their minds are given up to earthly things.[3:20] But we are citizens of heaven, and from heaven we expect a savior to come, the Lord Jesus Christ.[3:21] By the exercise of his power to bring everything into subjection to himself, he will make our humble bodies like his glorious body.

 [Philippians 4] 

[4:1] So then, my dear friends, whom I am longing to see – you who are my joy and my crown, stand fast in union with the Lord, dear friends.[4:2] I entreat Euodia, and I entreat Syntyche, to live in harmony, in union with the Lord;[4:3] yes, and I ask you, my true comrade, to help them, remembering that they toiled by my side in spreading the good news; and so, too, did Clement and my other fellow workers, whose names are in the book of life.[4:4] All joy be yours at all times in your union with the Lord. Again I repeat – All joy be yours.[4:5] Let your forbearing spirit be plain to everyone. The Lord is near.[4:6] Do not be anxious about anything; but under all circumstances, by prayer and entreaty joined with thanksgiving, make your needs known to God.[4:7] Then the peace of God, which is beyond all human understanding, will stand guard over your hearts and thoughts, through your union with Christ Jesus.

[4:8] In conclusion, friends, whenever you find things that are true or honorable, righteous or pure, lovable or praiseworthy, or if virtue and honor have any meaning, let them fill your thoughts.[4:9] All that you learned and received and heard and saw in me put into practice continually; and then God, the giver of peace, will be with you.[4:10] It was a matter of great joy to me, as one in union with the Lord, that at length your interest in me had revived. The interest indeed you had, but not the opportunity.[4:11] Do not think that I am saying this under the pressure of want. For I, however I am placed, have learned to be independent of circumstances.[4:12] I know how to face humble circumstances, and I know how to face prosperity. Into all and every human experience I have been initiated – into plenty and hunger, into prosperity and want.[4:13] I can do everything in the strength of him who makes me strong![4:14] Yet you have acted nobly in sharing my troubles.[4:15] And you at Philippi know, as well as I, that in the early days of the good news – at the time when I had just left Macedonia – no church, with the one exception of yourselves, had anything to do with me as far as giving and receiving are concerned.[4:16] Indeed, even while I was still in Thessalonica, you sent more than once to relieve my wants.[4:17] It is not that I am anxious for your gifts, but I am anxious to see the abundant return that will be placed to your account. I have enough of everything, and to spare.[4:18] My wants are fully satisfied, now that I have received from Epaphroditus the gifts which you sent me – the sweet fragrance of a sacrifice acceptable and pleasing to God.[4:19] And my God, out of the greatness of his wealth, will, in glory, fully satisfy your every need, through your union with Christ Jesus.[4:20] To him, our God and Father, be ascribed all glory for every and ever. Amen.[4:21] Give my greeting to everyone of the people of Christ Jesus. The Lord’s followers who are with me send your their greetings.[4:22] All Christ’s people here, and especially those who belong to the Emperor’s household, send theirs.

[4:23] May the blessing of the Lord Jesus Christ rest on your souls.


Paul’s Letter to the
--------------------

Colossians
==========

 [Colossians 1] 

##### Introduction #####

[1:1] From Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus, by the will of God, and from Timothy, also a follower of the Lord.[1:2] To Christ’s people at Colossae – the followers who are faithful to him: May God, our Father, bless you and give you peace.

[1:3] Whenever we pray we never fail to thank God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, for you,[1:4] now that we have heard of your faith in Christ Jesus and of the love that you have for all his people,[1:5] because of the hope which is kept safe for you in heaven. Of this hope you heard long ago in the true message of the good news which reached you,[1:6] bearing fruit and growing, as it does, through all the world, just as it did among you from the very day that you heard of God’s loving kindness, and understood what that loving kindness really is.[1:7] It is just what you learned from Epaphras, our dear fellow servant, who, as a minister of the Christ, faithfully represents us,[1:8] and who told us of the love with which the Spirit has inspired you.

[1:9] And therefore we, from the very day that we heard this, have never ceased praying for you, or asking that you may be filled with the knowledge of the will of God, which comes through all true spiritual wisdom and insight.[1:10] Then you will live lives worthy of the Master, and so please God in every way. Your lives will be fruitful in every kind of good action, and grow into a fuller knowledge of God;[1:11] you will be made strong at all points with a strength worthy of the power manifested in his glory – strong to endure with patience, and even with gladness, whatever may happen to you;[1:12] and you will give thanks to the Father who made you fit to share the lot which awaits Christ’s people in the realms of light.

##### The Person and Work of the Christ #####

[1:13] For God has rescued us from the tyranny of darkness, and has removed us into the kingdom of his Son, who is the embodiment of his love,[1:14] and through whom we have found deliverance in the forgiveness of our sins.

[1:15] For Christ is the incarnation of the invisible God – first-born and head of all creation;[1:16] for in him was created all that is in heaven and on earth, the visible and the invisible – angels and archangels and all the powers of heaven.[1:17] All has been created through him and for him. He was before all things, and all things unite in him;[1:18] and he is the head of the church, which is his body. The first-born from the dead, he is to the church the Source of its life, that he, in all things, may stand first.[1:19] For it pleased the Father that in him the divine nature in all its fulness should live,[1:20] and through him to reconcile all things to himself (making peace by the shedding of Christ’s blood offered on the cross) – whether on earth or in heaven.[1:21] And it pleased God that you, once estranged from him and hostile towards him in your thoughts, intent only on wickedness –[1:22] But now he has reconciled you to himself by the sacrifice of Christ’s earthly body in death – it has pleased God that you should stand in his presence holy, pure, and blameless,[1:23] if only you remain true to your faith, firm and immovable, never abandoning the hope held out in the good news to which you listened, which has been proclaimed among all created things under heaven, and of which I, Paul, was made an assistant.

[1:24] Now at last I can rejoice in my sufferings on your behalf, and in my own person I supplement the afflictions endured by the Christ, for the sake of his body, the church;[1:25] of which I myself became a minister in virtue of the office with which God entrusted me for your benefit, to declare the message of God in all its fulness –[1:26] That truth which has been hidden from former ages and generations. But now it has been revealed to God’s people,[1:27] to whom it was his pleasure to make known the surpassing glory of that hidden truth when proclaimed among the Gentiles – ‘Christ among you! Your hope of glory!’[1:28] This is the Christ whom we proclaim, warning everyone, and instructing everyone, with all the wisdom that we possess, in the hope of bringing everyone into God’s presence perfected by union with Christ.[1:29] It is for that I toil, struggling with all the energy which he inspires and which works powerfully within me.

 [Colossians 2] 

[2:1] I want you to know in how great a struggle I am engaged for you and for Christ’s people at Laodicea, and for all who have not yet seen me;[2:2] in the hope that they, being bound to one another by love, and keeping in view the full blessedness of a firm conviction, may be encouraged to strive for a perfect knowledge of God’s hidden truth,[2:3] even Christ himself, in whom all treasures of wisdom and knowledge lie hidden.[2:4] I say this to prevent anyone from deceiving you by plausible arguments.[2:5] It is true that I am not with you in person, but I am with you in spirit, and am glad to see the good order and the unbroken front resulting from your faith in Christ.

[2:6] Since, therefore, you have received Jesus, the Christ, as your Lord, live your lives in union with him –[2:7] rooted in him, building up your characters through union with him, growing stronger through your faith, as you were taught, overflowing with faith and thanksgiving.[2:8] Take care there is not someone who will carry you away by his ‘philosophy’ – a hollow sham! – following, as it does, mere human traditions, and dealing with puerile questions of this world, and not with Christ.[2:9] For in Christ the Godhead in all its fulness dwells incarnate;[2:10] and, by your union with him, you also are filled with it. He is the head of all archangels and powers of heaven.[2:11] By your union with him you received a circumcision that was not performed by human hands, when you threw off the tyranny of the earthly body, and received the circumcision of the Christ.[2:12] For in baptism you were buried with Christ; and in baptism you were also raised to life with him, through your faith in the omnipotence of God, who raised him from the dead.[2:13] And to you, who once were dead, by reason of your sins and your uncircumcised nature – to you God gave life in giving life to Christ! He pardoned all our sins![2:14] He canceled the bond which stood against us – the bond that consisted of ordinances – and which was directly hostile to us! He has taken it out of our way by nailing it to the cross![2:15] He rid himself of all the powers of evil, and held them up to open contempt, when he celebrated his triumph over them on the cross!

[2:16] Do not, then, allow anyone to take you to task on questions of eating or drinking, or in the matter of annual or monthly or weekly festivals.[2:17] These things are only the shadow of what is to come; the substance is in the Christ.[2:18] Do not let anyone defraud you of the reality by affecting delight in so-called ‘humility’ and angel-worship. Such a person busies themselves with their visions, and without reason are rendered conceited by their merely human intellect.[2:19] They fail to maintain union with the head, to whom it is due that the whole body, nourished and knit together by the contact and connexion of every part, grows with a divine growth.

[2:20] Since, with Christ, you became dead to the puerile teaching of this world, why do you submit, as if you still belonged to the world,[2:21] to such ordinances as ‘Do not handle, or taste, or touch’?[2:22] For all the things referred to in them cease to exist when used. You are following mere human directions and instructions.[2:23] Such prohibitions appear reasonable where there is a desire for self-imposed service, and so-called ‘humility,’ and harsh treatment of the body, but are of no real value against the indulgence of our earthly nature.

 [Colossians 3] 

[3:1] Since, therefore, you were raised to life with the Christ, seek for the things that are above; for it is there that the Christ is seated at the right hand of God.[3:2] Fix your thoughts on the things that are above, not on those that are on earth.[3:3] For you died, and your life now lies hidden, with the Christ, in God.[3:4] When the Christ, who is our life, appears, then you also will appear with him in glory.

##### The Gospel in the Daily Life #####

[3:5] Therefore destroy all that is earthly in you – immorality, uncleanness, passions, evil desires, and that greed which is idolatry.[3:6] These are the things because of which the wrath of God comes,[3:7] and to which you, like others, once devoted your lives, when you lived for them.[3:8] You, however, must now lay aside all such things – anger, passion, malice, slander, abuse.[3:9] Never lie to one another. Get rid of your old self and its habits,[3:10] and clothe yourselves with that new self, which, as it gains in knowledge, is being constantly renewed in resemblance to him who made it.[3:11] In that new life there is no distinction between Greek and Jew, circumcised and uncircumcised, barbarian, Scythian, slave, free; but Christ is all! – and in all!

[3:12] Therefore, as God’s people, consecrated and dear to him, clothe yourselves with tenderness of heart, kindliness, humility, gentleness, forbearance;[3:13] bearing with one another, and, when there is any ground for complaint, forgiving one another freely. As the Master freely forgave you, so you must forgive one another.[3:14] Over all these virtues put on love; for that is the belt which makes all complete.[3:15] Let the peace that the Christ gives decide all doubts within your hearts; for you also were called to the enjoyment of peace as members of one body. And show yourselves thankful.[3:16] Let the message of the Christ be alive in your minds in all its wealth, bringing all wisdom with it. Teach and admonish one another with psalms, and hymns, and sacred songs, full of the loving kindness of God, lifting your hearts in song to him.[3:17] And, whatever you say or do, do everything in the name of the Lord Jesus; and through him offer thanksgiving to God the father.

[3:18] Wives, submit to your husbands, as befits those who belong to the Lord.[3:19] Husbands, love your wives, and never treat them harshly.[3:20] Children, always obey your parents; for that is pleasant to see in those who belong to the Lord.[3:21] Fathers, never irritate your children, otherwise they might become disheartened.[3:22] Slaves, always obey your earthly masters, not only when their eyes are on you, as if you had but to please people alone, but giving them ungrudging service, in your respect for the Master.[3:23] Whatever you do, do it with all your heart, as if working for the Master and not for people,[3:24] since you know that it is from the Master that you will receive the inheritance which will be your reward. You are serving Christ, the Master.[3:25] Those who do wrong will reap the wrong they have done; and there will be no partiality.

 [Colossians 4] 

[4:1] Masters, do what is right and fair by your slaves, for you know that you also have a Master – in heaven.

[4:2] Devote yourselves to prayer. Give your whole mind to it, and also offer thanksgiving;[4:3] and at the same time pray for us, so that God may give us an opening for our message, so that we may speak of the truths hidden in the Christ – the truths for which I am in chains![4:4] Then I will make them known, as I ought to do.[4:5] Show tact in your behavior to the outside world, making the most of every opportunity.[4:6] Let your conversation always be kindly, but not bland, season it, as it were, with salt; be aware in each case of the answer you should be giving.

##### Conclusion #####

[4:7] Our dear friend, Tychicus, will tell you all about me. He is a faithful minister, and a fellow servant in the Master’s cause.[4:8] I send him to you expressly that you may learn our circumstances, and that he may give you encouragement.[4:9] With him will be Onesimus, our dear faithful friend, who is one of yourselves. They will tell you all that is going on here.

[4:10] My fellow prisoner, Aristarchus, sends you his greeting, and Barnabas’s cousin, Mark, sends his. (You have received directions about him. If he comes to you, make him welcome.)[4:11] Joshua, who is called Justus, also sends his greeting. These are the only converts from Judaism who have worked with me for the kingdom of God; I have found them a great comfort.[4:12] Epaphras, who is one of yourselves, sends you his greeting. He is a servant of Christ Jesus, and is always most earnest in your behalf in his prayers, praying that you may stand firm, with a matured faith and with a sure conviction of all that is in accordance with God’s will.[4:13] I can bear testimony to the deep interest he takes in you, as well as in the followers at Laodicea and at Hierapolis.[4:14] Luke, our dear doctor, sends you his greeting, and Demas sends his.[4:15] Give my greeting to the followers at Laodicea, and to Nymphe, and to the church that meets at her house.[4:16] And when this letter has been read to you, see that it is also read before the church at Laodicea, and that you yourselves read the letter which will be forwarded from there.[4:17] Give this message to Archippus – ‘Take care to discharge to the best of your ability the office to which you were appointed in the Master’s cause.’

[4:18] I, Paul, add this greeting in my own handwriting. Remember these chains of mine. God’s blessing be with you.


Paul’s First Letter to the
--------------------------

Thessalonians
=============

 [1 Thessalonians 1] 

##### Introduction #####

[1:1] To the Thessalonian church in union with God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, from Paul, Silas, and Timothy. May God bless you and give you peace.

##### The Apostle and his Converts #####

[1:2] We always mention you in our prayers and thank God for you all;[1:3] recalling continually before our God and Father the efforts that have resulted from your faith, the toil prompted by your love, and the patient endurance sustained by your hope in our Lord Jesus Christ.[1:4] Friends, whom God loves, we know that he has chosen you,[1:5] because the good news that we brought came home to you, not merely as so many words, but with a power and a fulness of conviction due to the Holy Spirit. For you know the life that we lived among you for your good.[1:6] And you yourselves began to follow, not only our example, but the Master’s also; and, in spite of much suffering, you welcomed the message with a joy inspired by the Holy Spirit,[1:7] and so became a pattern to all who believed in Christ throughout Macedonia and Greece.[1:8] For it was from you that the Lord’s message resounded throughout Macedonia and Greece; and, more than that, your faith in God has become known far and wide; so that there is no need for us to say another word.[1:9] Indeed, in speaking about us, the people themselves tell of the reception you gave us, and how, turning to God from your idols, you became servants of the true and living God,[1:10] and are now awaiting the return from heaven of his Son whom he raised from the dead – Jesus, our deliverer from the coming wrath.

 [1 Thessalonians 2] 

[2:1] Yes, friends, you yourselves know that your reception of us was not without result.[2:2] For, although we had experienced suffering and ill treatment, as you know, at Philippi, we had the courage, by the help of our God, to tell you God’s good news in spite of great opposition.[2:3] Our appeal to you was not based on a delusion, nor was it made from unworthy motives, or with any intention of misleading you.[2:4] But, having been found worthy by God to be entrusted with the good news, therefore we tell it; with a view to please, not people, but God who proves our hearts.[2:5] Never at any time, as you know, did we use the language of flattery, or make false professions in order to hide selfish aims. God will bear witness to that.[2:6] Nor did we seek to win honor from people, whether from you or from others, although, as apostles of Christ, we might have burdened you with our support.[2:7] But we lived among you with the simplicity of a child; we were like a woman nursing her own children.[2:8] In our strong affection for you, that seemed to us the best way of sharing with you, not only God’s good news, but our lives as well – so dear had you become to us.[2:9] You will not have forgotten, friends, our labor and toil. Night and day we used to work at our trades, so as not be a burden to any of you, while we proclaimed to you God’s good news.[2:10] You will bear witness, and God also, that our relations with you who believed in Christ were pure, and upright, and beyond reproach.[2:11] Indeed, you know that, like a father with his own children, we used to encourage and comfort every one of you, and solemnly plead with you;[2:12] so that you should make your daily lives worthy of God who is calling you into the glory of his kingdom.

[2:13] This, too, is a reason why we, on our part, are continually thanking God – because, in receiving the teaching that you had from us, you accepted it, not as the teaching of humans, but as what it really is – the teaching of God, which is even now doing its work within you who believe in Christ.[2:14] For you, friends, began to follow the example of the churches of God in Judea which are in union with Jesus Christ; you, in your turn, suffering at the hands of your fellow citizens, in the same way as those churches did at the hands of their people –[2:15] who killed both the Lord Jesus and the prophets, and persecuted us also. They do not try to please God, and they are enemies to all humanity,[2:16] for they try to prevent us from speaking to the Gentiles with a view to their salvation, and so are always filling up the measure of their iniquity. But the wrath of God has come upon them to the full!

[2:17] As for ourselves, friends, our having been bereaved of you even for a short time – though in body only, and not in spirit – made us all the more eager to see your faces again; and the longing to do so was strong on us.[2:18] That was why we made up our minds to go and see you – at least I, Paul, did, more than once – but Satan put difficulties in our way.[2:19] For what hope or joy will be ours, or what crown will we have to boast of, in the presence of our Lord Jesus, at his coming, if it isn’t you?[2:20] You are our pride and our delight!

 [1 Thessalonians 3] 

[3:1] And so, as we could bear it no longer, we made up our minds to remain behind alone at Athens,[3:2] and sent Timothy, our dear friend and God’s minister of the good news of the Christ, to strengthen you, and to encourage you in your faith,[3:3] so that none of you should be shaken by the troubles through which you are passing. You yourselves know that we are destined to meet with such things.[3:4] For, even while we were with you, we warned you beforehand that we were certain to encounter trouble. And so it proved, as you know.[3:5] Therefore, since I could no longer endure the uncertainty, I sent to make inquiries about your faith, fearing that the Tempter had tempted you, and that our toil might prove to have been in vain.[3:6] But, when Timothy recently returned to us from you with good news of your faith and love, and told us how kindly you think of us – always longing, he said, to see us, just as we are longing to see you –[3:7] on hearing this, we felt encouraged about you, friends, in the midst of all our difficulties and troubles, by your faith.[3:8] For it is new life to us to know that you are holding fast to the Lord.[3:9] How can we thank God enough for all the happiness that you are giving us in the sight of our God?[3:10] Night and day we pray most earnestly that we may see you face to face, and make good any deficiency in your faith.

[3:11] May our God and Father himself, and Jesus, our Lord, make the way plain for us to come to you.[3:12] And for you, may the Lord fill you to overflowing with love for one another and for everyone, just as we are filled with love for you;[3:13] and so make your hearts strong, and your lives pure beyond reproach, in the sight of our God and Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus, with all his Holy Ones.

 [1 Thessalonians 4] 

##### Advice on Daily Life #####

[4:1] Further, friends, we beg and urge you in the name of our Lord Jesus to carry out more fully than ever – as indeed you are already doing – all that you have heard from us as to what your daily life must be, if it is to please God.[4:2] For you have not forgotten the directions that we gave you on the authority of our Lord Jesus.

[4:3] For this is God’s purpose – that you should be pure; abstaining from all immorality;[4:4] each of you learning to gain control over your own body, in a way that is holy and honorable,[4:5] and not for the mere gratification of your passions, like the Gentiles who know nothing of God;[4:6] none of you overreaching or taking advantage of their fellow follower of the Lord in such matters. The Lord takes vengeance on all who do such things, as we have already warned you and solemnly declared.[4:7] For God’s call to us does not permit of an impure life, but demands purity.[4:8] Therefore the person who disregards this warning disregards, not people, but God who gives you his Holy Spirit.

[4:9] As to love for each other there is no need to write to you; for you have yourselves been taught by God to love one another;[4:10] and indeed you do act in this spirit towards all his people throughout Macedonia.

Yet, friends, we beg you to do even more.[4:11] Make it your ambition to live quietly, and to attend to your own business, and to work with your hands, as we directed you;[4:12] so that your conduct may win respect from those outside the church, and that you may not want for anything.

##### The Dead in Christ at the coming of the Lord #####

[4:13] We don’t want you to be ignorant, friends, about those who have passed to their rest. We don’t want you to grieve like other people who have no hope.[4:14] For, as we believe that Jesus died and rose again, so also we believe that God will bring, with Jesus, those who through him have passed to their rest.[4:15] This we tell you on the authority of the Lord – that those of us who are still living at the coming of the Lord will not anticipate those who have passed to their rest.[4:16] For, with a loud summons, with the shout of an archangel, and with the trumpet-call of God, the Lord himself will come down from heaven.[4:17] Then those who died in union with Christ will rise first; and afterward we who are still living will be caught up in the clouds, with them, to meet the Lord in the air; and so we will be for ever with the Lord.[4:18] Therefore, comfort one another with what I have told you.

 [1 Thessalonians 5] 

[5:1] But as to the times and the moments, there is no need, friends, for anyone to write to you.[5:2] You yourselves know well that the day of the Lord will come just as a thief comes in the night.[5:3] When people are saying ‘All is quiet and safe,’ it is then that, like birth pains on a pregnant woman, ruin comes suddenly upon them, and there will be no escape![5:4] You, however, friends, are not in darkness, that the daylight should take you by surprise as if you were thieves.[5:5] For you all are children of light and children of the day.

We have nothing to do with night, or darkness.[5:6] Therefore let us not sleep as others do. No, let us be watchful and self-controlled.[5:7] It is at night that people sleep, and at night that drunkards get drunk.[5:8] But let us, who belong to the day, control ourselves, and put on faith and love as a breast plate, and the hope of salvation as a helmet.[5:9] For God destined us, not for wrath, but to win salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ, who died for us,[5:10] that, whether we are still watching or have fallen asleep, we may live with him.[5:11] Therefore encourage one another, and try to build up one another’s characters, as indeed you are doing.

##### Conclusion #####

[5:12] We beg you, friends, to value those who toil among you, and are your leaders in the Lord’s service, and give you counsel.[5:13] Hold them in the very greatest esteem and affection for the sake of their work. Live at peace with one another.[5:14] We entreat you also, friends – warn the disorderly, comfort the faint-hearted, give a helping hand to the weak, and be patient with everyone.[5:15] Take care that none of you ever pays back wrong for wrong, but always follow the kindest course with one another and with everyone.[5:16] Always be joyful;[5:17] never cease to pray;[5:18] under all circumstances give thanks to God. For this is his will for you as made known in Christ Jesus.[5:19] Do not quench the Spirit;[5:20] do not make light of preaching.[5:21] Bring everything to the test; cling to what is good;[5:22] shun every form of evil.[5:23] May God himself, the giver of peace, make you altogether holy; and may your spirits, souls, and bodies be kept altogether faultless until the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.[5:24] He who calls you will not fail you; he will complete his work.

[5:25] Friends, pray for us.

[5:26] Greet all the Lord’s followers with a sacred kiss.[5:27] I order you in the Lord’s name to have this letter read to all the brethren.

[5:28] May the blessing of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.


Paul’s Second Letter to the
---------------------------

Thessalonians
=============

 [2 Thessalonians 1] 

##### Introduction #####

[1:1] To the Thessalonian church in union with God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, From Paul, Silas, and Timothy.[1:2] May God, the Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you and give you peace.

##### The Apostle and his Converts #####
